Snow safety morning.  We did a full snow safety route in Near Wagon Wheel.  We did a second pass to detail cornice prior to giving snow safety clearance.  Kip kicked a chunk of cornice and it broke and he fell onto the slope with it, fracturing a 6" crown and triggering a small avalanche.  We talked about where he wanted me to kick cornice and he said there was a chunk to the skiers left he wanted me to kick.  I kicked it and it broke off about the size of a small table.  When it hit the slope the slope propagated and fractured, stepping down into multiple layers, and slid approximately 400' with Kip.  Kip mostly stayed on the surface, fighting and swimming, with hand up, avoiding major injury and not losing any gear.  He immediately communicated back to me by radio he was OK.

Cornice kicking and ski cutting were effective to release slope and mitigate hazard.  Both employees involved had Tracker Beacons, Probes, Shovels and Radios.  Avalanche Dog Chewy was in service at closest duty station, Chair 6.  Kip was not injured

From NPS news release:
"An avalanche on Mt. McKinley's West Buttress during the early morning hours of June 14, 2012 is presumed to have claimed the lives of four Japanese climbers. The five-member Miyagi Workers Alpine Federation (MWAF) expedition was descending Motorcycle Hill near 11,800-feet at 2:00 am Thursday morning when an avalanche swept them all downhill. The five were travelling as one rope team, although the rope broke during the avalanche. One team member survived the event.Hitoshi Ogi, age 69 of Miyagi Prefecture, was swept into a crevasse and subsequently climbed out with minor injuries. Ogi was unable to locate his teammates in the avalanche debris. Throughout the day, Ogi descended solo to the Kahiltna Basecamp at 7,200 feet, where he reported the accident shortly after 4:00 pm.

That evening, two NPS rangers flew to the avalanche path in the park's A-Star B3 helicopter to conduct an aerial hasty search. There was no sign of the missing climbers or their gear in the avalanche debris.In light of the time elapsed, it is presumed that the four perished in the accident. NPS rangers and volunteers began probing the debris zone on Friday to look for signs of the climbers."

location_name: South Lookout Peak, near Ophir Pass
description:
A group of 2 snowboarders descended a north aspect from a prominent saddle near South Lookout Peak (13,357 ft), in the Ophir Pass area. They descended the main couloir and then moved to the west, entering a cross-loaded gully. The two snowboarders moved one at a time down the gully. Rider 1 stopped on the fresh wind slab about two-thirds of the way down the gully to watch Rider 2. Rider 2 made one or two turns on the wind-loaded side of the gully, then made a sharp turn towards the east away from the slab. As Rider 2 made this turn he saw a crack shoot up slope. The moving avalanche debris quickly piled onto his snowboard and he was knocked off of his feet.
The avalanche took Rider 2 through a narrow slot in a cliff band and out of Rider 1's view. Rider 2 went over two small cliff/rock bands disappearing in the moving snow at times but generally staying on top of the flowing debris. Rider 2 came to rest about 10 feet up slope from the toe of the debris, on his back, head uphill.
The combined forces of the avalanche and hitting rocks during the ride knocked Rider 2's splitboard bindings out of alignment, shattered their goggles, and damaged his helmet. Rider 2 was able to travel out of the backcountry with the assistance of Rider 1 and another group that was touring in the area.
The avalanche released on a north-facing, above-treeline slope. It was a soft-slab avalanche, small relative to the path but large enough to kill a person(SS-ARu-R2D2-I). The avalanche did not break into old snow layers. We estimate the crown face was 12 to 18 inches deep and 100 feet wide. The debris ran approximately 300 feet vertical.

Skier 1 descended the slope while the other members of the party watched from the summit. He made several turns before dropping over a convexity. As he descended the convexity, avalanche broke ~50â€™ above him. Skier 1 disappeared quickly, engulfed in fast-moving snow.

A second group (group #2) had landed on the ridge LZ and was preparing to ski the run behind group #1. The LZ is high on the ridge and the ski run is not visible from this spot. As group #2 was organizing on the LZ, the avalanche occurred and group #2 was unaware of the event. A third group (group #3) was in flight for the same ridge and witnessed a large powder cloud in the valley. Group #3 informed group #2 of the avalanche, but told group #2 to hold on the ridge due to "hang fire". Group #3 guide contacted base to initiate the operation EMS plan, landed mid-slope at the top of the debris pile and began the course search. The helicopter (279CH) left guide #3 and flew to the ridge to pick up guide #2 on the ridge. It was determined at that time that two person were missing from group #1 including the guide. Also during this time, a second helicopter was dispatched to the accident site with three additional senior guides from base.

location_name: Ranger Peak, Grand Teton National Park
description: Both were caught in the avalanche and carried down the mountain then buried by the avalanche debris in the run-out zone of the avalanche path. Upon receiving an overdue report from one skier's father later that night, a search and rescue response was initiated the next morning. A helicopter was sent to search Waterfalls Canyon where the crew located articles of equipment on the surface of a recent avalanche. The two missing men were then found using a beacon receiver suspended beneath the helicopter. The bodies were dug out of the debris by Grand Teton rangers approximately 24-26 hours after the avalanche incident.

The first two snowmobiles crossed the avalanche path and regrouped on the other side in the more protected part of the meadow. As the third snowmobile made its way across, the first two started to see "snow dust" coming down the avalanche path and waved the third on. As the third made it to the first two, the fourth snowmobile (victim) crested over the top of the steep hill and into the avalanche path. Vigorously waving for him to cross, the "snow dust" turned into a powder cloud and then debris and powder cloud obscured their vision for over 30 seconds. Once the snow settled, the fourth snowmobile and his rider was nowhere to be seen. The party started to search for their partner immediately.

Unfortunately, the party only had one beacon, one probe and two shovels. They started their search from the last seen point and realized the force of the avalanche pushed the victim off the bench the summer road was on and into a classic terrain trap: a steep gully. They had a very good feeling where he was buried: probed all over the place, yet their probe could not reach the bottom of the debris (which in some places was over 30' deep). There was a potential probe strike: the party dug a six foot hole in this location...they were losing time. Approximately 1 hr 45 min elapsed during this search and the party realized they were outmatched to find their companion. They left and found cell service way down John Brown's Canyon on the way to Gateway. The accident occurred around 10:30 am and Grand County Search and Rescue received the call on 2:00 pm.

location_name: SE of Grouse Mountain, Togwotee Pass
description: The rider was reported to have been the second person to high mark the slope. The previous rider who was not involved in the avalanche had taken a less bold ride on this steep south to southeast facing slope. The second rider, who was caught, was near the top of the slope when it failed. He was carried downhill and buried in a head up position to a depth of three feet below the snow surface. avalanche debris converged in the burial area at the base of the slope and was estimated to be up to 18 feet deep.

Skiers 1 through 5 were in the gully bottom, while Skiers 6 through 8 were above the incident site in a location upstream in the gully. Skier 1 moved past Skiers 2 through 5 to a point 15 feet away from the group. Skier 1 then collapsed the slope and triggered the avalanche from below but was not caught. At the same time Skier 6 was descending into the gully, upstream from where Skiers 2 through 5 were located. Skier 2 was directly in front of Skier 3, and â€œwas able to push out of the way of the avalancheâ€ and Skiers 5 and 6 were further upstream of the slide. The avalanche caught Skiers 3 and 4. Skier 3 was partly buried-critical, with only a hand above the debris. Skier 4 was fully buried. Skiers 3 and 4 were buried 6 to 10 feet apart. Skier 7 descended to the avalanche site after hearing that the avalanche occurred, while Skier 8 remained in a safe location above the incident site.

At the point where he could see the ridge above was beginning to dip and the steep north face starting to flatten, the companion left the road and began an ascending side hill climb into the relatively open stand of fire killed snags. Compared to snowmobiles, motorized snow bikes are far more adept at side hilling. After traveling only a short distance he felt the snow collapse and saw the steep slope above him breaking. A wave of snow soon hit and threw him from his machine, at which point he swam and fought to stay on the surface. Luckily he missed colliding with any of the snags. When the moving snow came to a stop, he was facing downhill, somewhat on his stomach, head out of the snow, buried mostly up to his chest. Looking around he expected to see Rider 1 riding up, thinking that he was some distance behind. Instead he could see or hear nothing of his friend.

While digging himself out, the companion said he then noticed Rider 1’s snow bike was 50-70 feet above him, lying on its side above a snag. Suddenly a hand popped out of the snow a short distance above and east of the companion’s position. The companion struggled to free himself, digging at the snow with his hands. Since beginning to ride snow bikes he said he seldom carried a shovel. In addition to being blocky, the avalanche debris was dense, icy, and set hard, “like concrete.” After considerable struggle and quite some time the companion was able to free himself. Using his cell phone he called 911 and rushed to Rider 1’s position and again began digging with his hands. He said that the protruding hand that earlier had been moving was now motionless. When finally uncovered by a recovery party, Rider 1 was reportedly buried face down.

Unexpectedly and without warning the avalanche impacted the three riders on the road, completely burying Norm and partially burying Jason and David. Jason was able to free himself and Davidâ€™s arm was sticking out of the snow. Brent was only slightly buried. Jason, Brent and Clint uncovered David who was unharmed. Darren and Clayton arrived on scene moments later. The group realized Norm was missing and turned their avalanche transceivers to receive. Normâ€™s signal was quickly picked up and the group had Norm dug out within ten minutes.

As they rode, the companion watched his friend depart from the road. Within the blink of an eye he saw fast moving snow descending the slope above them. The companion reported that he had no time to react. Before he could hardly shift his gaze from the moving snow upslope to look ahead, searching for an escape opening, he was hit from the left by the avalanche. He tumbled with his snowmobile initially and fought to stay on top of the flow by swimming. He said he swam, and swam, and swam! Then suddenly he came to a stop and could see his hand in front of this face. He could hear his machine idling somewhere further down slope. His thoughts immediately turned to Rider 1. He knew Rider 1’s position in that last second prior to the avalanche’s impact. He knew Rider 1 was upslope only 20-25 feet from a group of three or so trees nearly at the road’s edge.

location_name: WAC Bluffs near Aplental Ski Area
description: At this point and near the middle of the pocket, with the victim in the middle, the party triggered the slab which released approximately 20 ft. above the victim. The first boarder was not caught while the last member of the party was caught but not in the main slide and was able to self-arrest. Unfortunately the middle boarder was caught and subsequently swept down through the choke of the chute/cliff/ice bulge area. The loading and frictional effects from the first slide triggered another 16-18 inch slab fracture on a lower bench, with the resulting slide mass carrying the victim over multiple cliffs and rock bands onto the runout at the base of the cliff area, a total distance of about 400 vertical feet (~3400 ft elevation.

Just before noon a group of 15 skiers made the short hike to the top of Cowboy Mountain from the 7th Heaven Chair, exited the Stevens Pass Mountain Resort, and entered the back country. The group consisted of locals and visiting skiers, all experienced backcountry skiers equipped with avalanche rescue gear. Skiing one at a time, the first six skiers negotiated the top meadow of the popular Tunnel Creek area to then wait in various locations in the trees on the skiers left…just prior to traversing to another meadow. At around noon, the seventh skier entered the meadow and on his third turn triggered the 2-3 ft slab avalanche that would catch him and three of the six who were waiting below (although one other skier was also caught, he was able to arrest by grabbing a nearby tree). The avalanche funneled the four skiers into the very dangerous creek drainage/gulley beneath them and the valley floor runout some 2400 vertical feet below (see Figures 4-7 below showing route of avalanche). Owing to many objective dangers including exposed rock outcrops, trees and other obstacles, the skiers had not intended to ski the very steep and winding gulley into which the avalanche descended…planning instead to traverse skiers left into a series of meadows before hitting the more open terrain near the power lines.

location_name: Gibbs Creek, near Wolf Creek Pass
description:
Skier 2 descended the slope. He probably triggered the avalanche at a roll-over where the slope abruptly steepened. There were rocks extending through the bed surface, though the party saw no indications of shallow snow prior to the avalanche. The crown was about 50 feet uphill of Skier 2. The avalanche propagated far to the skier's left.

The avalanche caught Skier 2. It carried him through the glade and into the timber below. He was fully buried on the uphill side of a tree, about 5 to 6 feet deep. The avalanche stripped away much of his equipment, including his helmet.

The avalanche caught Skier 3 near the crown. He was dragged downhill by the flowing snow, hit several trees, but was not buried. Skier 3 was injured and lost a ski.

Skier 1 heard the avalanche coming and saw it flow past the trees. Debris did flow through the dense trees. There was little force left by the time it reached Skier 1, and he was buried to his knees and able to sidestep up and out.

A group of three skiers entered Mushroom Bowl around 11 AM on February 13th. The three skiers were along a north aspect cliff band (About 11,400 feet) with Skier 1 furthest west along the cliffs. Skier 1, 2 and 3 were in voice communication but could not see each other. Skier 2 and 3 were aware that Skier 1 would go off the cliff first. At about 11:30 Skier 1 came almost to a stop before jumping off an approximately 30 foot high cliff. When Skier 1 hit the slope a fracture propagated across the slope, about 100 feet wide, directly under Skier 1's feet. Skier 1 tried to cut left to get off the slab but the fracture continued to propagate left and Skier 1 was swept off his feet. Skier 1 tried to grab a small tree but was pulled off by the moving debris. Soon after this Skier 1 was swept through some smaller trees. Skier 1 hit a few of these trees with his left side and broke some ribs. Skier 1 continued to fight to keep his skis downhill and soon came to rest near the toe of the debris, on his left side, facing downhill. At this time Skier 1 was not buried too deeply, they could see light, but more debris quickly buried him about 1 to 1.5 feet deep at the head. Skier 1 was able to move one hand and could build a small air pocket. Skier 1 said he quickly knew he had to relax and slow his breathing down (it was very painful to breath with the broken ribs). He knew Skier 2 and Skier 3 would be down soon to get to him so he relaxed as best he could. A part of one ski was visible above the avalanche debris and it was still attached to Skier 1. Skier 2 & Skier 3 did not see the avalanche. But they heard it "We heard what sounded like a freight train". Shouts for Skier 1 were not returned.
Skier's 2 & 3 were able to negotiate a route off the cliff. They were careful not to trigger a second slide so this took maybe a couple of minutes.
Skier 2 & Skier 3 started a beacon and visual search down the avalanche path. About 5 to maybe ten minutes after the avalanche Skier 2 and 3 saw Skier 1's ski at the same time they got a beacon signal. In all Skier 1 felt he was buried 10 to maybe 15 minutes before he was fully excavated.
Skier 1 (with help from Skier 2 & 3) was able to self evacuate approximately 2 to 3 miles to Gold Peak where he met a friend who drove him to the nearby hospital.
The slide was rated a SSASR2D2O. The slab dimensions were 30" deep at the crown by an estimated 100 feet wide by 300 feet vertical. Skier 1 was carried down the entire slope and was partially buried critical just up hill from the toe of the debris pile.

Snowboarder traveling alone was caught, carried 925 vertical feet, and buried in an avalanche in a backcountry area south of the town of Telluride. Two riders from a different group came upon the avalanche and performed a companion rescue, but the victim was already deceased.

The avalanche occurred in a below treeline area of the Bear Creek drainage, locally know as Contention. The avalanche started in an area to the west of the main gulley known as the Fingers. The start zone has an easterly aspect.

The victim was waring an avalanche airbag and an Avalung. Both were deployed but damaged beyond use in the avalanche.

Media Reports: Telluride Watch Denver Post

Avalanche details: HS-ASr-R2-D2-I
Type: Wind slab
This was a 1finger hard wind slab sitting on a thin layer (2" and less) of 4finger hard low density powder over harder (pencil hardness) wind slab that acted as the bed surface. Size estimate: 150' wide, running 5-700' x 12-18" deep Trigger: Remote from ~20-30' left from corner of the right flank and stauchwall. (see photo)
Weak Layer: Broken precipitation particles/decomposing fragments
Aspect: WNW
Angle: 37-43 degrees
Elevation: 2500'
Debris: ~3-5' deep (fanned out to varying degrees)

Weather: Storm day.
Friday Feb. 10th, the day before the avalanche, 8-12â€ of medium density snow fell with 30mph east winds, gusting to 85mph. Temperatures near 30F. Saturday Feb. 11th, the day of the avalanche, 3-5â€ of similar, medium density snow fell with east winds averaging 40mph and gusting to 95mph. Temperatures near 30F.

Avalanche danger rating: CONSIDERABLE with pockets of HIGH.

Events:
The avalanche was remotely triggered by a skier from a safe, flat, ridged section of the slope just above treeline. That person felt a "collapse" which propagated to a higher elevation adjacent 37-43 degree slope and the avalanche resulted. Five skiers were stopped at this safe area and two were still hiking up in lower angle terrain below.

The debris overran a shallow depression and was deposited on a sub-ridge/bench terrain feature with sparse trees. The two skiers still hiking were in this lower angled terrain when the debris caught them. They were believed to have been carried 150-200' with one skier partially buried and one fully buried. The latter was buried under just inches to, at most, 1 foot of snow and wedged against a small tree. The five remaining skiers mounted an excellent quick and efficient rescue. Beacons were used to locate the skier fully buried when one person noticed a hand. At this point, they were able to clear the airway and the skier was able to breath on their own. It was estimated to take as little as 3 minutes, but possibly more, from the time of the avalanche to clearing the airway. The skier partially buried was able to dig most of himself out and help with the rescue of his partner. Both buried skiers were able to ski out on their own power.

Note:
The debris from this avalanche nicked one small 50' section in the zig-zag of the 'relatively' safe up-track (where skiers were caught). A small section of the up-track was also covered with a very small amount (1' or less) of debris near the toe.

At the end of the day, the group was going to exit the backcountry and they were looking for the fastest route out. They chose to utilize a summer road that crossed an avalanche path. Rider B had traveled down the road the previous week and his tracks were still visible. It was 5pm or a little later. He started up the road and was about half way across the path when he felt the entire pack move. The next thing he knew, he was being pushed off the road. He then said that snow was washing over him and he was engulfed. Luckily, he was not knocked off the sled and was able to grab a full handful of throttle which propelled him back out of the churning snow and he was able to ride to safety.

When he came to a stop, riders C and D were on the opposite side of the path and had not been caught. Rider A was no where to be seen. They speculated that Rider A had been following Rider B and had been buried but none of them had seen him get caught.

On Wednesday, 2-1-12, a cornice fall dropped a skier onto the steep, rocky slope below, triggering a large slab avalanche in the northern section of the Jewel Basin Hiking Area, NE of Bigfork. A party of two skiers was traversing the crest of the Swan Range between Twin and Wildcat Lakes at the time of the incident. The second individual was not caught and later alerted 911 of the incident. Because of the unsafe conditions and no reasonable access from the ridge, he was not able to conduct a search himself. Organized rescue efforts Wednesday were turned back by poor visibility and darkness. The skierâ€™s body was recovered the next day, Thursday, 2-2-12.

location_name: Little Giant, West Kessler, Big Cottonwood Canyon
description:
On the morning of Saturday January 28th, a party of three backcountry tourers headed up the Argenta avalanche path of Kessler Peak in BIg Cottonwood Canyon for a day of powder skiing and riding. The party soon gained the northwest ridge of Kessler Peak and made a plan to descend West Kessler, also known as Little Giant. The first person to drop in, a 25 year old male snowboarder, immediately triggered a 2-3' deep hard slab avalanche, carrying him an estimated 2400' vertical down the slope. He was completely buried near the toe, or bottom of the slide.

His two companions switched their avalanche transceivers to receive, descended the slope and extricated their friend, buried under 3' of debris. Soon thereafter, rescuers from Wasatch Backcountry Rescue arrived, evacuated the victim and his companions, and returned to the helibase. The victim suffered injuries incompatible with life.

Rising above 10,200', Kessler Peak stands abruptly above the other peaks in mid-Big Cottonwood Canyon and is surrounded by radical terrain and avalanche paths on all sides. It harbors two significant avalanche paths that directly threaten Big Cottonwood Canyon and it was in one of these - Argenta - that the party chose to ascend the peak.

The line that the party intended to descend on West Kessler is known as Little Giant. It is a steep, convoluted series of chutes and chokes with many rocky outcrops and trees along the way. At least one and perhaps two other separate avalanche paths converge into the lowest choke at a rough elevation of 9000'. It was reported that the victim travelled over 2400' down this slope and was buried very near the bottom, or toe of the debris.

The crown measured by GIS software is over 1000 feet wide.

On the day of the avalanche, the advisory's bottom line read, "Very dangerous conditions exist in the backcountry.

There is a CONSIDERABLE avalanche danger for triggering deep slab avalanches and a MODERATE danger for triggering any new or old wind drifts. Itâ€™s not HIGH danger anymore, but the travel recommendations remain the same. Iâ€™d avoid the steep west to north to southeast facing slopes at the mid and upper elevations.

Four riders going one at a time jumped off a southern ridge of Glacier Mountain and onto a northeast aspect slope. Rider 1 or 2 was reported triggering small sluffs, but they did not observe any other signs of instability. At least one rider had a hard fall about one third of the way down slope after encountering a hard layer of snow (possibly a wind crust).  
Rider 5 accessed this same path from Deer Creek and approached the path to look for a route onto the slope. Rider 5 walked around for a bit looking at different entrance possibilities. She opted for the wider entrance to the path, did not jump in, but rode onto the same slope previously ridden by Riders 1 through 4. Within the first ten feet Rider 5 hit a rock (which is about the time that the video starts). Three turns after hitting the rock Rider 5 noticed some cracking and turned to look up-slope. Rider 5 saw a crack open up and then made a move towards a pre-determined escape route about 50 feet further down slope and to the rider's right. Soon after this Rider 5 was knocked off her feet and noticed the snow buckling down slope. At this time Rider 5 realized she was in a bigger slide and thought "I'm caught". Rider 5 then pulled the ripcord on their airbag pack and rode the slide down slope, feet first, in a sitting position. The whole event seemed to "Move surrealy slow" but was probably over in 20 to 30 seconds. Rider 5 stopped in a sitting position with feet down slope, not buried and uninjured.

We believe Skier 1 followed a traverse into the Trestle Trees. The area had seen some ski traffic, including ski patrollers. Skier 1 cut along low angel terrain below a short, very steep rock outcrop. He probably triggered the avalanche from below. Slight terrain features funneled the majority of the avalanche towards Skier 1. The avalanche caught Skier 1 from the side and behind, and knocked him over. He was fully buried two to three feet deep, face downhill, with one had reaching towards the surface.

On Sunday January 22, a skier triggered a large avalanche on Diamond Peaks, near Cameron Pass. The avalanche was triggered from low-angle terrain near treeline, and propagated several hundred feet uphill. The avalanche over-ran the low angel terrain and continued into the avalanche tracks below treeline. The avalanche "swallowed" the skier and his dog, and carried them about 100 feet across the low-angle terrain.

Skier 2 waited at tree line while Skier 1 moved out across the bench. "About 50-60ft out of the trees" the snowpack collapsed. Skier 1 turned around, "and soon as I turned my partner started yelling." An avalanche had started well above Skier 1. "I looked up and saw a slower moving wave" low on the face. "About half way up there was a second wave that was twice as big [as the first] and was running way faster than the first. "

Skier 1 was halfway back to the trees when the combined waves hit him like a "wall that was about head high." Skier 2 saw Skier 1's arm pop up briefly. "I remember this because I saw sky and got a breath of air for a second. After that I was back under the snow and my partner lost sight of me again until it settled."

When the avalanche stopped, Skier 1 was partly buried. His head, a shoulder and arm were above the debris. His dog may have been fully buried, because the dog "popped out" after the avalanche stopped.

At approximately 11:30 pm, Subject 1 and 2 were climbing up and across a 35 degree slope above a forested bench. They were about 10 feet apart when the avalanche released. They were both caught in the avalanche. Subject 1 was washed downhill and completely buried uphill of a small conifer tree. Subject 2 was quickly washed into a large conifer tree and partially buried, non-critical.

(Second had report): On January 22, a snowmobiler was caught and fully buried in a small avalanche near Cameron Pass. The snowmobiler was at the base of a short cut-bank and triggered the avalanche. The abrupt transition to the flat road created a terrain trap, and the debris piled up deep enough to fully bury the snowmobiler.The avalanche ran about 20 vertical feet, and may have bee about 60 feet wide. The snowmobiler was fully buried. The avalanche and rapid rescue was caught on video.

Skiers 1, 2, and 3 were all caught in the avalanche. Skier 1 was the furthest south on the slope. The avalanche carried Skier 1 through the spruce forest until he came to rest against a tree, partially buried-critical with both skis and one arm above the snow surface.  The burial location was approximately 50-75 feet below a traverse track present on the day we visited the site (January 23, 2012). The avalanche carried Skier 2 until he struck and grabbed a tree. He lost both ski poles and gloves in the ride and one ski was knocked off. The tree where Skier 2 came to rest was very near the traverse track present on the day we visited the accident site. The avalanche knocked Skier 3 off a small cliff. He tumbled and when he came to a rest, he was out of the debris and not buried.

Skier 3 entered the same gully another 25 lower than Skier 2 on a short, but very steep northeast facing slope. Skier 3 skied straight down the fall line of this slope without turning and into the gully bottom. He became stuck low on the slope in the debris from the small avalanche triggered by skier 2 and the weak faceted snow below that debris pile. While struggling to get out of the snow and move downhill, he triggered a small soft-slab avalanche on the sidewall of the gully. This avalanche ran down into the gully, knocking skier 3 over and burying him in debris at the bottom of this terrain trap.

location_name: Flat Top Mountain, southeast of Yampa
St. Mary's Glacier, northeast of Berthoud Pass
description:
Details are sparse at this point.  There were two climbers ascending a rocky east-facing slope above the north end of St. Mary's Lake apparently aiming to top out near point 11716 on the USGS topo map. While ascending, they triggered a hard slab, 2-3 feet thick and 70 feet wide. The slab ran approximately 400 vertical feet over a small cliff band, and avalanche debris washed down two gullies on either side of the rocky cliff feature to the west edge of St. Mary's Lake. It is not known for certain at this point how far the victim was carried in the debris, nor whether or not he was washed over the cliff and/or down one of the gullies.  Tracks coming down the bed surface from the crown of the avalanche and through the debris indicate the victim was likely carried over the cliff band. There are two sets of tracks exiitng the debris near the lake.
The victim sustained minor injuries to his ankle, and banged up his head during the slide. Fortunately, he was wearing a helmet.

location_name: Second Creek headwall near Berthoud Pass
description:
Skier 2 descended from the ridge. He skied a short way down on low angled terrain to a small grassy knob on the skier's left of the face. From there, Skier 2 could see the entire run. Skier 1 then traversed south towards the skier's right side of the face. The plan was for him to ski to the right of the rock knob, about two thirds of the run, then tuck into a safe spot below the knob and spot Skier 2.

Skier 1 made several turns before the avalanche broke. He was about 150 to 175 feet below the crown face. He heard Skier 2 shout and tried to move left, off the slab. He "made little progress" and the avalanche quickly engulfed him. He was "definitely airborne" during the avalanche. The avalanche covered his face, but he could see light and was able to push up and get his face above the debris as the avalanche stopped. He was looking uphill and could see Skier 2 descending.

From mtstandard.com:

"A 20-year-old Butte man died ... when his snowmobile triggered an avalanche in that same area east of Red Lion.

Rescue crews from Georgetown Lake and Anaconda could not revive the man, whose name was not immediately released."

Late Friday afternoon, December 30th, the victim (aka. A1), his wife (aka.B2), and dog Ole, drove to Cooke City (7,600â€™) for a backcountry ski tour the next day. According to a friend they were aware the GNFAC had issued an Avalanche Warning that denoted all slopes had a High danger in the Cooke City area. Saturday morning, on telemark skis, they climbed a marked trail along Woody Creek out of town following a set of ski tracks broken by local BZ and his partner.

Approximately 1.5 mile into the ski A1 and B2 ran into BZ who was retreating because of the High avalanche danger. BZ and his partner had triggered a slide on a steep 50 foot hill next to the creek which buried his partner to the waist. They continued onward through open meadows, but turned around at the Wyoming border because of the danger. They spoke to A1 first with B2 arriving half way through the conversation. According to BZ, they told the couple about the avalanche they triggered and the reason they were heading out. A1 and B2 continued a half mile further to the end of BZâ€™s tracks at the border, at which point they turned on their avalanche transceivers. A1 was wearing a digital Ortovox Patroller while B2 had a dual frequency F2 Ortovox with earpiece powered by rechargeable batteries. The F2 was last made in 1989. After turning on the F2, A1 told B2 that the battery power was not great.

A1 was intent on following a route described in the ski guidebook, Nine Months of Winter, now out of print. They broke trail up Hayden Creek for another mile through the flat meadow. B2 does not remember seeing the avalanche BZ and his partner triggered, but she does remember widespread collapsing as they skied. They were both nervous about it. Per the guidebook, they veered to the east up a side drainage leading towards Index Peak. The terrain changed quickly from open fields to a 20 foot wide canyon bordered by 50 foot rock walls. They entered the narrow canyon and skied another half mile. It was cold and windy and they wanted to eat lunch. A1 made a hard right turn (south) through a break in the gully, an avalanche path, in search of a more comfortable spot. B2 followed a few minutes behind. A1â€™s decision to go to the right might have been influenced by the guidebook he was referencing. From their position in the creek with regards to avalanche danger, â€œto avoid slopes fraught with more imminent perilâ€¦you can play it smart and ski into the trees on the right and make your way up to the Basin in them.â€

They went no more than a few hundred feet up the path when A1 saw a small avalanche and yelled a warning to B2. They were both ascending the left side of the 50 foot wide path. She grabbed a tree. She could not see A1, but assumed he did the same. The collapse propagated uphill and released a larger avalanche above them. The avalanche fully buried A1 and just missed B2. The time was 1420.

B2 skied uphill expecting to find A1, but soon realized he was buried. She turned her avalanche transceiver on â€œreceiveâ€, put her earpiece in and started searching. She could only get a signal when the volume was on its highest setting making it impossible to pin-point. Weak batteries were likely the cause of this malfunction. B2 searched the debris and dug multiple holes in the snow. She spent until approximately 1700 on the scene looking for A1. Getting dark she headed back to town solo. The dog was buried too.

In town, Cooke City SAR was already mobilized from another avalanche fatality involving a snowmobiler earlier that afternoon. When B2 arrived she gave the SAR coordinators information on the avalanche. Three snowmobilers headed into the scene that night, located A1 and extricated him back to town.

For this report I interviewed BZ on Monday, January 4, 2012 while Eric Knoff interviewed B2 the night of the avalanche. We also got many more details from the family in the days after the avalanche.

A1 had 22 years experience backcountry skiing and B2 a few years. In the early 1990â€™s A1 took an Introduction to Avalanches with Field Course offered by the GNFAC at MSU. B2â€™s avalanche training was informal. The day of the accident both A1 and B2 carried avalanche transceivers and shovels.

At approximately 11:50 am on December 31st, the victim, Rider 1, his son Rider 2, and a companion, Rider 3, accessed the northeast face of Henderson Mountain via a tight drainage above Fisher Creek. Rider 3 stopped at the top of the drainage while Rider 1 and Rider 2 continued up the open face, angling right to avoid the steepest section of the slope. Rider 2 continued veering right onto a less steep sub-ridge.

Rider 1 continued to climb up and left into steeper and more exposed terrain where he triggered the avalanche. Rider 1 was able to execute a downhill turn and was traveling down-slope when the avalanche caught him. He was carried 500-600 vertical feet downhill where he was entirely buried, except for the heel of his boot which was sticking out of the snow. His snowmobile was entirely buried, except for a small section of the right ski, approximately twenty feet below Rider 1.

Both Rider 3 and Rider 2 witnessed the slide, but lost sight of Rider 1 in the debris. Rider 3 was near the bottom of the slope and deployed his BCA air bag as he watched the slide move towards him. Fortunately he was not caught. Rider 3 and Rider 2 turned their transceivers to receive and began a search. Rider 3 found Rider 1â€™s boot sticking out of the snow in a matter of minutes. After discovering Rider 1â€™s boot, Rider 3 descended the steep drainage and informed other party members of what had happened. During that time Rider 2 began shoveling out his father. In a matter of minutes Rider 3 arrived back on scene with additional party members. They found Rider 1 face down with his head buried 2-3 deep, not breathing and with no pulse.

The group had Rider 1 completely unburied in 10-12 minutes after the avalanche occurred. Members of the group immediately initiated CPR. CPR had been in progress approximately 20-25 minutes before members of the Cooke City Search and Rescue arrived on scene. An AED was applied, but no shock was advised. At this time myself and partner arrived on scene. CPR was conducted for approximately 45 minutes before a physician in Cooke City gave notification to end CPR. Shortly after CPR was called off a member of the Cooke City search and rescue arrived on scene with a toboggan. The victim was taken to the Cooke City Fire Hall.

Every member of the party was experienced in mountain snowmobiling and had ridden the area numerous times. Each rider carried rescue gear and knew how to use it. They had seen a sign in the Exxon station saying the avalanche danger was HIGH. They did not see the daily advisory issued by the GNFAC. Rider 2 attended MSU and participated in an avalanche awareness course 10 years ago.
Skier 1 saw the snow break into pieces. Skier 1 descended to the point where he saw Skier 2's tracks enter the avalanche. He did not see his partner.

Two men in their 30s left the closed Alta ski area with the intent to ride the well known terrain of Alta and Snowbird. Neither ski areas are open yet and have yet to conduct any avalanche control within their boundaries. We interviewed the victim's ski partner. To say he was shaken up is an understatement.

While neither had any rescue gear or formal avalanche training, they were both expert skiers and knew the terrain well. They had not consulted the avalanche advisory that morning in which the danger was rated Considerable to High. They continued to Snowbird via Baldy and accessed the Peruvian Cirque to gain the Gad Valley. While ascending out of the Peruvian Cirque they remotely triggered a large avalanche that covered their tracks that they had just made. It's unclear whether they realized they had triggered this large avalanche. They gained the ridge and prepared to drop into Gad Valley.

With the partner watching, the victim dropped into the slope, immediately triggering the slide. He was carried approximately 800 feet through steep rocky terrain and reportedly went over a small cliff band and came to a stop only partially buried. The partner went down to help the victim and called for a rescue, alerting both the Snowbird Ski Patrol and Wasatch Backcountry Rescue, who subsequently accessed and evacuated the victim.

While removing skins, I stood about 50ft higher than my other party members in the other chute. We were separated by a small rock band but could see and communicate with each other clearly. I finished preparing my gear before the others (AT setup), deployed my avalung tube and got ready to drop in. I cut a hard right turn followed by another hard left at about the steepest part of the slope (~40 degrees). I slowed almost to a complete stop to make my next turn to avoid a scree field 300ft below me. In the next instant I felt immense pressure surrounding my feet, and they were quickly taken out from under me. I quickly gained speed and was unable to move from this point on. In my panic I was unable to yell "Slide!" to alert my party. Due to the separation of the chutes by the rock band, my party was unaware I was in an avalanche for several seconds. Realizing my situation I immediately started to push against the snowpack in an effort to remain on top. In a panic to stay on top of the slide, I was unable to place the avalung tube in my mouth.   While I was fighting all three members confirm that they had eyes on me for several seconds, and then lost me beneath the snow pack. As I kept pushing and fighting, snow started to come above my head, and my party members lost sight. A second later, the whole snowpack "jumped", and I was able to push myself on top, where my party members again regained sight of me. As the slide continued to pick up speed I was dragged into the large boulder scree field I had tried to avoid earlier. I braced for impact using my skis as a shield, bouncing off 2 to 3 boulders before the slide finally slowed and came to a stop.

Snowboarder #1 (the first person descended)caught in a small soft slab avalanche and swept around 1000 vertical feet through some rocky terrain. 

The second and third members of the group (two skiers) descended the same route to reach the victim.  They arrived at the victim at approximately 1:25pm, and quickly realized they needed to go for help. They did not have cell phone coverage at the site of the accident, so Skier #2 traversed out and back to Kelso Ridge at 1:35 pm, and descended the north side of Torreys into Grizzly Gulch to make his way back to Bakerville where he was able to get cell phone reception. Skier #3 stayed at the site of the accident to attend to the victim. Skier #2 reached Bakerville and made the 911 call at 2:37 pm.
Skier #3 began moving the victim down slope at approximately 2:00 pm. They had descended approximately 400 vertical feet before the first search and rescue members reached them at between 5:30 and 5:40 pm.

location_name: Rocky Mountain National Park, near Embryo Lake
description:
"Three of us were proceeding back to the Glacier Gorge parking area after reaching Sky Pond in Rocky Mountain National Park. We were following rocky ridgelines as much as possible to avoid the [potential avalanche] danger. We saw no signs for slides but with occasionally swift winds of 15-25 mph downslope all day, and some light snow, we knew it was advisable to be prudent. The previous week had seen consolidation of underlying layers, but there was evidence of some 4" - 6" of new snow in the Park as we drove in and as we moved above timberline. On the return we exercised caution, until we were at the final slope above the trees near Embryo Lake. I did not have my GPS with me this trip but we had been in the same area twice previously in the past month so we were familiar with the area. I pole probed the snow at the slope and saw no signs of slides in the zone, no sign of previous slide activity on this slope, and the run out was free of large boulders and trees. Everyone wanted to glissade the way down to the treeline and our trail back. I was the only three who has had avi training (Level 1 two years ago) and had my shovel and probe, but no beacon because I knew [the others in the party] had no avi gear and no training. Because I was still cautious, I asked them to let me go first and wait until they saw me clear before they began their descents. The going on my butt was slow at first, and I hardly needed my poles to brake my descent. But very shortly the convex slope turned concave and the angle increased. About the same time as I began to move a little faster the wind came from behind in ground blizzard force, and made the visibility hazy, as it was all white. I did have goggles one which helped me to notice that I was suddenly moving down at a pretty good clip, and then looked around to see many fracture lines and could see now what was happening. As I descended I swam backstroke style and then rolled towards the outer edge of the slide, attempting to exit it out the side before we bottomed out. But the concavity of the slope poured the snow toward a central location, like edges of a great tarp tipping inward and downward. I was on top swimming and felt focused and in the moment, but was yet surprised when I came to a halt at the bottom that the event was not over. In the last two seconds after my forward progress halted, the snow that had collected from behind me piled in and buried me except for my head and one arm. I was happy to be free of course, and began to dig out. I knew the [other two] were still above and could see them coming down around the perimeter of the wide fracture lines, as they did not want to risk another slide, since only a shallow 6" or so slid. I managed to get my camera free and take some shots from the burial site up and in of the girls to the side, and that's how I know the time of the event.

It was a soft landing and I'm happy the outcome was benign, but recalling the whole incident reinforces what I've always been taught, that the snow in a slide solidifies immediately upon coming to rest in a dense, concrete-like state that would not permit easy removal. I had my poles in the hand that was buried under 3' of snow and could have slid it free if necessary, but did not want to let go until my friends could dig me out because I thought I might not find them under the snow again. The [others] also dug out my legs and feet, which still had the snowshoes on.
The avalanche caught the rider and carried them over 100 vertical feet. The rider was partly buried and self-rescued. The rider sustained minor injuries.

location_name: Garnet Canyon Meadows, Grand Teton National Park

description: Snowboarder jumped onto slope, made one turn, and immediately released some loose snow that triggered main slide. Snowboarder attempted to stop above slide, but was pulled down with the crown.

location_name: Highlands Ridge, Desolation Row, Aspen zone
description: The avalanche path, Desolation Row, drops from the Highland Peak ridge line down into the Maroon Creek valley. The group entered this path just above treeline on a west facing rib that made up the skiers right side of the path. They spaced out and skied one at a time for several short pitches down this initial section. As the group reached treeline elevations, they made a traverse to the skiers left side of the bowl into northwest facing terrain. On this traverse, the group again moved one at a time. The fourth skier moved quickly across this traverse and near the end of it, triggered a slab avalanche from a shallow spot in the snowpack. The crown face of this avalanche was only 6-8 inches deep at the trigger point. It quickly propagated across the slope and became much deeper.  Skier number 5, towards the end of this traverse, got very close to the 4th skier in an effort to shoot some video with a camera he carried. He was caught in and killed by the avalanche that was triggered just in front of him. One contributing factor to this accident was the lack of distance between the 4th and 5th skiers during their traverse.

location_name: Green Mountain, west side of Independence Pass
description:
According the the party involved "The slide broke on my first ski cut at least 300 yards above me on a cross loaded slope above treeline (we were at treeline) and took me for a short, but very scary ride down it's skiers right flank and spit me out on a small bench a quarter of the way down the slide path as the rest of the mountain side went- all the way to the ground. I was only partially buried and was able to self rescue"

The avalanche did result in one broken ski and damaged a snowmobile parked on the road below the path. Damaged estimated at $1000.00.

Once above the top of the "Tool", the two discussed conditions and their plan to film the run. Skier1 descended into the left entrance of the gully stopping at a "safe spot". From here, the plan was to film Snowboarder2. While setting up, he dropped one of his gloves, which slid about half way down the steep gully. Snowboarder2 voiced his plan for the filming and mentioned that he would pick up the glove on the way down. Snowboarder2 dropped into the line making a handful of turns, picked up the glove and rode out to the skiers left side of the path to what he thought was a safe zone. 
Skier1 descended down, meeting up with Boarder2. Skier1 voiced that he wanted to get out of there and was concerned that things were "heating up". Snowboarder2 wanted him to continue filming and said that he wanted to be filmed going off a wind pillow on the skiers right side. Skier1 again voiced that he wanted to get out of there and put his camera away. Snowboarder2 continued with his plan, cutting across the slope (a planned slope cut) to the right side. As Snowboarder2 got close to the rock wall, Skier1 noticed how hard the snow surface was saying â€œHis snowboard made a cut into the slab.â€ Skier1 then noticed a fracture propagating across and behind Snowboarder2. Both the skier and snowboarder were caught on the slab and were just below the fracture line. 
Snowboarder2 tried to ride out of the slide to the right but quickly became entrained. 
Skier1 rode the slab the entire way, passing several trees. Skier1 thought he would be able to ski off of the slab but he caught a tree with his right ski and immediately knew he broke his leg. He came to a stop as the debris stopped moving and fell over on his left side. He called 911 almost immediately. He could not see Snowboarder2 but quickly established verbal contact with a rescue whistle. The skier knew he was close, but could not help as he felt immobilized with a broken leg.

location_name: Back country to the west of Stevens Pass, WA. Backside of Cowboy Mountain
description: Group of 4 snowboarders were descending the back side of Cowboy Mountain toward US 2 late Sunday PM. One of the group jumped off a rock and subsequently triggered a WL-AR slide (estimated as R2D2). The approximately 5-600 ft vertical slide carried the victim into a gulley and through trees where he received fatal injuries. The victim was found mostly buried and extricated within ~15 minutes by others of his party. Unfortunately the victim did not respond to CPR.

At that point C & D were standing near the edge of the cornice which suddenly gave way. C fell with the VW Bus sized piece of cornice that broke off and triggered the large avalanche.  C was carried almost all the way down the avalanche path.  Viewing from above, D saw C get up and start moving around and for a moment the group thought they had dodged a bullet.  They soon realized that A & B had also been caught and carried by the avalanche.  D instructed E, F & G who were waiting in the snowcat to call 911 which they did as there is cell service at this location.  This call was placed around 11:45am & EMS was mobilized.

location_name: Chair Peak, NW shoulder above Snow Lake, WA

description: In poor visibility, walked off the scoured east-west ridgetop to find some shelter from extreme south winds, approaching trees downslope. As snow got deeper, slight rib flattened out and turned into a rollover. Knowing this wasn't good, I stopped to peer through the fog, when the snow a couple feet below me cracked about 6" deep with a slight Pop. As the sluff hit the rollover, the slope cracked ~50' to either side, leaving a crown approx. 2' deep. This ran downslope to the trees, about 30-40 yards, then disappeared over a steeper rollowver (that I hadn't before been able to see). No one was caught in it.

Two experienced backcountry skiers approached the "Sunnyside" run, on the ESE face of Hatch Peak near 5:00pm on March 19th, 2011. There were apporximately 6 tracks on the slope from earlier that day. Skier 1 skied down first and staged midway down the slope in order to spot skier 2. After skier 2 made a few turns into the run he felt the slide initiate. By using swimming motions he was able to self-rescue off the moving debris onto the side. Once out of the debris, skier 2 realized he had injured his leg. He did not see skier 1 on, or near, the slide path or on the debris. His lower leg injury did not allow him to begin companion rescue. He initiated a rescue using an emergency locator beacon. Skier 1 was swept down the gully and buried 14 feet deep.

He quickly thought of his exit route, angling at a 45* angle to his right. He grabbed a hold of the first tree and held tight. The slab passed by him quickly and it was over. His partner then came down to join him via a similar route. They called "911" to report it, saying they were okay.

location_name: Pinnacle Gully, Huntington Ravine, Mt. Washington NH
description:
(following is a press release that has been amended to provide more info for this form)

A 31 year old NH man fell approximately 1150â€™ after triggering an avalanche in Mount Washingtonâ€™s Huntington Ravine on Thursday, March 10, 2011.  While solo ice climbing in the Ravineâ€™s Pinnacle Gully, the mountaineer began to climb down due to his concerns about unstable snow.  While descending, the slope fractured and avalanched, carrying him down the gully, through the approach area named â€œthe Fanâ€, to the Ravine floor.  Although receiving significant injuries he was deposited on top of the snow and was able to dial 911 and report his accident at roughly 10:45AM.  U.S. Forest Service Snow Rangers were notified and responded with the caretaker from the Harvard Mountaineering Club cabin.  Rangers traveled from Tuckerman Ravine on snowmobiles with rescue equipment and arrived on scene at 11:15AM.  The patientâ€™s injuries were stabilized, he was packaged into a rescue sled and transported behind a snowmobile to the Pinkham Notch Visitor Center where he was transferred to an ambulance and brought to Memorial Hospital in North Conway.
  
The avalanche danger for Pinnacle Gully on Thursday was rated at â€œConsiderableâ€ by the U.S Forest Service Snow Rangers at the Mount Washington Avalanche Center.  This rating was based on new snow being transported into Pinnacle Gully by south winds.  Between 7.3â€ (18 cm) and 8â€ (20 cm) of new was recorded from the storm before it changed over to rain on Friday.  It is unclear how much snow had fallen at the time of the avalanche, but field estimates were around 4â€ (10 cm).  Winds out of the south had been recorded on the summit of Mt. Washington in the 40 and 50 mph (65 and 80 kph) range since snow began falling around 2:00 am, Thursday morning.  The avalanche was triggered in new wind slab that was sitting on a rain crust.  The avalanche was classified as D2R3

Pinnacle Gully is a very popular three pitch snow and ice climb in Huntington Ravine.  It faces primarily east and slope angles vary from grade III water ice to snow slopes between 20 and 60 degrees.  Avalanche activity often occurs in the exit of the gully (start zone) or below the first pitch of ice on the approach.  We were unable to verify the exact location of the crown line of this avalanche due to unfavorable weather conditions.  The victim thought that he triggered approximately 3/4 of the way up the gully, which is about 400 linear feet of grade II-III ice climbing.

The victim described himself as being a competent ice climber who gets out 4-5x/week throughout the season. The climb was well within his technical ability, but we have no information at this time about his avalanche knowledge or training. His wife described him as a very cautious climber with regards to avalanches and was surprised by his involvement with an avalanche. The avalanche advisory for Huntington Ravine is conspicuously posted at the Harvard Mountaineering Club cabin each morning and was available at the time he would have passed by here.

Rider 1 skied the slope with no problems and tucked into a spot behind some trees where he could watch Rider 2. Rider 2 began down the slope with his Avalung in his mouth. He did a ski cut just left of Rider 1's tracks and got no results, so continued to turn down the slope. A large sluff initiated on Rider 2's third turn. This turned into a soft slab, which propagated across the slope. Rider 2 saw refrigerator-sized chunks of snow breaking around him and tried to escape. He was tumbled and snow packed into his goggles, but he managed to get his board on his downhill side. The slide moved fast and Rider 2 could feel his board hitting trees on the way down the slope. He hit a tree with his chest, but was wearing body armor, which tempered the blow.

Rider 2 felt the slide slowing and was near the surface, but went over one last convexity before the slide stopped. At this point he was fully buried and unable to move. He remained calm while breathing through his Avalung, awaiting rescue from his partner. His goggles, ears and lips surrounding his Avalung were all packed with snow and all was black around him. He initially had trouble breathing due to tightly packed snow all round him, but this slowly improved with time.

Meanwhile, the avalanche had propagated to Rider 1's "safety" spot. He was caught in the avalanche, lost both skis and poles, and was partially buried.

Avalanche kills Leavenworth skier
By Rachel Schleif
Wenatche World staff writer
Sunday, March 6, 2011


LEAVENWORTH â€” A 28-year-old backcountry skier died in an avalanche on Mount Cashmere Saturday afternoon, March 5, 2011.

Z of Leavenworth was skiing with a group of people on the southwest face of Mount Cashmere above Trout Creek, when an avalanche swept him about 800 feet down a coulee and through a small group of trees, according to a press release from the Chelan County Sheriff's Office. No one else was injured.

People skiing with Z stayed at the scene in an attempt to save him, while others skied and rode snowmobiles out of the area to find cell phone reception. Dispatch records show they called 911 at about 4:16 p.m.

A Medstar helicopter and search and rescue team were dispatched immediately. By the time rescuers made it to an area north of Z's location, it was determined that he had died of his injuries.

Due to high avalanche danger and impending darkness Saturday night, mountain rescue personnel returned Sunday morning to recover his body.

Two skiers had already skied on line in the Gulf of Slides on this day.  On their second run, the first skier found soft slab as he came over a convexity in the slope in the start zone.  He skied toward his pre-established safe zone when the slope failed.  The slab propagated approx. 300' and he quickly found that his safe zone wasn't safe.  The avalanche swept him off his feet and carried him down the entire path.  He reported that he was buried at times but was able to swim to the surface as the debris stopped and he escaped uninjured.  It is estimated that the fracture line was about 300' long, 1 to 3' deep and ran appoximately 900' (D2R3).  The individual involved and his partner were each equipped with a beacon, probe and shovel and were conciously skiing one at a time.

Gunbarrel Cutbank is a short, steep slope just south of Monarch Mountain Ski Area.
Two avalanches occurred in the Gunbarrel Cutbank on February 27. The first ran around 1 PM, and was triggered by a snowmobiler. Debris from the first avalanche covered a portion of the westbound lane. CDOT personnel stopped traffic while they removed the snow.
A skier triggered, was caught, and buried in the second avalanche. It was about 400 feet north of the first. Witnesses in stopped cars watched the avalanche occur, and ran to alert CDOT. CDOT personnel and witnesses converged on the avalanche. They spotted about 6 inches of ski pole above the debris and began to dig. They quickly reached the skierâ€™s face two to three feet deep. He was already â€œblue in color.â€ Monarch Mountain Ski Patrol arrived a few minutes later, but the skier did not require first aid.

location_name: North Face San Bernardo Pk, Lizard Head Pass
description: Steep roll at top of alley, several hundred feet below ridge, convex roll, 2 ft crown, then stepped down another foot to ground.  Skier did one full roll then skied/swam to side of slide, was taken 20 meters while slide went 400' vertical and stopped on bench (rather then run all the way to Wilson Creek).  Crown was 70 feet across, slope had only one tree in it.

Snowboarder was booting up the gully with his dog and planned on stopping when he reached a cliff that separates the upper and lower sections of the gully.  As he approached 5m from the mid-gully cliff an avalanche presumed to be naturally triggered came out of the top section.  Along with his dog he was swept 250m down the gully and deposited on the top of the debris.  He was badly injured but crawled a few meters up the debris to where his pack was partially buried (it had ripped off him) and called 911.  He was transported to the hospital where they found him to have a broken pelvis, three broken vertebrae, four broken ribs and a concussion.

location_name: East Snowmass Creek Valley, Sand's Chute
description: Once in Sand's Chute, the group skied one at a time. Since they had observed blowing snow, they expected any avalanches to be small, shallow wind slabs. They did not expect avalanches to break into deeper snowpack layers. The first skier descended and pulled out into a safe zone. The second skier entered the path and triggered the  avalanche on approximately his third turn. He was caught, carried, and fully buried in the avalanche.

Both riders were caught in the avalanche. Rider 2 was caught in the portion of the slide that came down from the east-facing portion of the bowl. There was not much debris on this side and when the debris stopped, Rider 2 was only partially buried. Rider 1 was  completely buried by the avalanche. Rider 2 grabbed his shovel and turned his avalanche beacon to receive. Rider 1 was not wearing an avalanche beacon so Rider 2 did not pickup a signal. Rider 2 started digging in the snow for Rider 1. After 45 minutes to an hour, he decided to go for help.

Group was ascending left flank of a 45 degree slope making steep switchbacks from the edge of the trees to about 20 feet into the slope.  The lead skier was approximately a third of the way up the slope making the third switchback (toward the trees) when the slope released.  The second skier was at the second switchback approximately 5 feet from the trees.  The third skier was between the first and second switchback with the fourth skier at the first switchback.  The lead skier was swept approximately 50 feet down slope into skier three who was attempting to hold on to a small tree.  Those two travelled another 20-30 feet, proximate to skier four and all came to rest in the debris field partially buried.  Skier two was swept into trees approximately 20 feet below and pinned there and partially buried.  All skiers came to rest with heads above the snow.

Descending one at a time, A1 went first.  He boarded over 1,300 feet, almost to the bottom of the slope.  He waited a few minutes for his dog to catch up when he saw an avalanche powder cloud come down the gully.  He put on his skins and went to the toe of the debris.  He did not get a signal, so he dialed 911 since he knew the rescue was not going to be simple.  He continued up the debris until he got a signal.  He hit B2â€™s boot with his probe and began digging.  Responding to the 911 call, which got routed to Gallatin County Search and Rescue (GCSAR), Bridger Ski Patrollers Pete Maleski arrived at the scene first, followed minutes later by Phil Scamma.  Excavating B2 was difficult because the hard slab debris was dense.  Nine minutes later they had B2 extricated, but he was deceased.  B2 was in a face down, head downhill position with his foot 1-2 feet from the surface and his head 5+ feet deep.  A1 noted that B2â€™s binding looked like he intentionally released it before getting fully immersed in the avalanche. 

The terrain in Truman Gulch is complex and the snowpack is highly variable.  Steep ridges and gullies lead into trees and over cliffs.  The terrain demands constant attention to navigate safely and even small avalanches can result in serious injury or death.  Sixty mph winds cross loading this terrain created hard slabs on the edges of gullies which further complicated snowpack analysis.  The avalanche broke above their highest point (did it break there or propagate to there?) and wiped out their two snowpits and area where they geared up to descend. 

I interviewed A1 in person the day of the accident.  The next day Mark Staples, Eric Knoff and I (GNFAC), Karl Birkeland (National Avalanche Center), Randy Elliott (General Manager, Bridger Bowl) and Pete Maleski (Snow Safety Director, Bridger Bowl) went to the crown.  Staples, Knoff and I continued to the bottom.

location_name: South Side of Hollywood Headwall, Frazier Basin, Northern Bridger Mountains.
description: Skied out of the entry chute. When the chute opened up wider the snow broke. The roughly 2 feet of fresh snow was on top of a firm slick layer. The new snow released and slide down on top of the hard layer. Below the chute to the left was a ridge line that we planned on skiing skiers left to in case something slide. I faced skiers left in the slide, keeping my head up hill, one arm under the other's arm pit and the other over my head for air pockets. I kept trying to dig my edge into the firm layr below and make it as far to the skiers left as possible. I was able to make it far enough to the outskirts of the slide. I was buried up to my waist, but the snow was light and I was able to kick out. We figured the slide took me about 1000 feet.

The victim was reported by friends and family to have gone on a solo ski tour to Red Mountain on Tuesday February 1st.  It is presumed that the victim triggered the cornice fall while walking/standing on the summit.  The victim and cornice fell about 600' to the slope below.  A small loose avalanche (R1D2) was triggered from the cornice fall.  This slide ran about 400 vertical feet.  The victim was found buried under 30cm of snow about 100' up from the debris toe.

Skier 1 went first, and descended the slope without incident. Rider 2 went and met Skier 1 at the decided "safe" spot well out into flat terrain. The third person (Rider 3-snowboarder)took a few turns and came out below the rock bands onto the open 'apron'. As Rider 3 made one more turn, they heard a whumph and looked up slope and saw no slide, they then looked back down slope and that is when the slab fractured. The fracture ran into both adjacent slopes producing avalanches to bot the north and south of the slope they were descending. Rider 3 was pushed forward down into the snow and carried under the snow. Rider 3 immediately made an air pocket with her arms and when the air pocket filled with snow she resorted to swimming to try and reach the surface. Rider 3 quickly reached the surface as the avalanche slowed and then stopped. Rider 3 ended up laying horizontally, facing down slope with only their legs and feet buried in the snow.

Rider 1 reports that he went under the flow of the debris, but ended up on top. He was carried approximately 800' by the slide. Rider 1 sustained life threatening injuries in the accident. Quick thinking, quick extrication and a location that had cell reception and close accessibility to the highway all contributed to a fast self-rescue.

A solo backcountry skier triggered a soft slab avalanche in the West Willow drainage just outside the boundaries of the Snowmass Ski area. He was caught and fully buried in the avalanche. Another party in the area spotted the fresh avalanche and a moment later noticed this buried skier "pop up" out of the debris.

location_name: "High Trail Cliffs," northeast of Berthoud Pass
description: Rider 2 was buried face down and head pointed downhill. His head was under about 18 inches of avalanche debris. His dog was buried next to him. It appeared that Rider 2 took a diagonal descent when the avalanche started. He was caught and buried at the toe edge of the debris and may have been very close to outrunning the avalanche.

While toproping The Shroud ice climb, an avalanche from above the climb flowed through the area.  The climber on the ice at the time was generally protected just below the top of the ice flow and the avalanche ran over him.  The belayer was not anchored in and was swept from his stance at the belay station.  The belayer was unable to hold the break on the belay device and slid approximately 30 feet down the rope where a knot stopped him from being carried away by the avalanche and releasing the climber above.  The snow flowed over the climber and pummelled the belayer for approximately 10 seconds and then continued past the climbers.  Neither party was injured or buried as the two climbers held each others weight at the end of the rope through the secure toprope anchor.  The slide reached the bike/ski/snowshoe path at the base of the slope approximately 400 to 500 feet below.

location_name: Above Cemetery avalanche path, Red Mountain Pass, North San Juans
description:
[A party of four] started the tour from Red Mountain Pass. [They toured to the summit ridge. From there they] sought out a low-angle gully to make it down to the trees [Above Cemetery avalanche path.] Descending off the ridge, we were regrouping and incrementing our way down. I was in the lead and threading my way down a shallow and snaky gully that the wind had scoured...I was trying to skirt a large rollover to our right that tightened my sphincter a bit.

As I stopped, I heard the others shouting my name. Looking up, I saw what looked like someone sitting in the snow. It was [Rider 2, on a splitboard,] sitting in the snow...up to her knees in avalanche debris. She rode a few feet out of the gully and onto the rollover, which immediately released. [Riders 3 and 4] were off to side and above her, out of the avalanche. [Rider 2] had to dig herself out and was thankfully unharmed.

The slope we were descending was probably 20-25 deg, but the small rollover to the right of our gully was probably in the low to mid 30s. As the avalanche forecast had mentioned and we empirically got to verify, â€œpocketsâ€ of instability did still remain above treeline, due to NW wind loading from the previous storm. The slope above the rollover had been wind scoured nearly to the grass/ground.

location_name: Lee Vining Canyon, CA.  2nd chute skiers left of V-bowl

description: One or two turns on to the slab I saw a fracture down-slope from me, and immediately tried to dig in with my edges and pole grips. The slide knocked me off my feet, so I was sitting on top of the slab at the top of the slide. A few seconds later it stopped.

location_name: 4 Jeffrey's campground below Bardini Canyon, Inyo County, California
description: Skier reported the following. "I attempted to ski cut this slope from the top. Body weight alone triggered a slab 12 inches deep, propagating ~100 ft across the top of the slope and running for 200-300 ft." Skier was not caught in the avalanche.

On Monday December 20th, a solo backcountry skier triggered a soft slab avalanche on a north aspect of Marble Peak, in the Yule Creek valley. The avalanche was triggered from low on the slope. The crown was located at around 11,200 ft and estimated to be 20 inches deep. It ran about 100 yards down the slope.

The skier was partially buried with his skis about three feet below the surface. He was able to dig himself out and and skin back to the ridge.

The rider was moving very slowly on low angle terrain when he saw the cracks. He "pulled into [the] rocks, thought I was out of path and would watch it go by."

The rider was hit by a "freightliner" of snow from above. He was instantly buried. He triggered his airbag and "floated to the surface as I heard the bag inflate." He was able to swim to the edge of the avalanche, and came to a stop after about 100 feet, partly buried under 6 to 18 inches of snow. "Below me was a [rocky area] that would have destroyed me, period."

The avalanche continued over the rocks and to the valley bottom. There were "car...sized blocks" left in the starting zone, and debris piles deeper than the party's 3 m probes. The rider's sled was buried and found the following day.

location_name: Peak 13,419 near Eureka, North San Juans
description: Climber 1 was in the lead. He triggered a shallow avalanche. The crown broke a few feet above him, and was less than a foot deep. Climbers 2 and 3 were about 25 feet below, dusted by debris, but sheltered from the full force by rocks. Climber 4 was about 150 feet below. He was caught and buried to his waist.

location_name: Gilmore East Peak - Meadow Lake, Lemhi Range
description: Summary available at: http://nopiste.blogspot.com/2010/12/voice-from-within.html

Subject 2 was caught in the slide and quickly lost site of his friend and also tried to escape further into the treed ridge to the west, but did not make it before being swept up in the debris. Subject 2 quickly lost both skis (AT set-up) and began to tumble down slope with the slab. At some point Subject 2 found himself under the snow with his head uphill. He had an Avalung which was partially in his mouth when he came to. He had a small air pocket and was able to move an arm and begin digging his way out of the debris. Subject 2 did not know if he was completely buried, as he was somewhat dazed after being swept through multiple small Sub-alpine fir and Engleman spruce saplings. Upon escaping the debris Subject 2 called for Subject 1 with no response, and not knowing whether Subject 1 was above or below began a beacon search uphill first.

location_name: Morning Star Peak, north central Washington Cascades
description:
A solo climber left the trailhead (with dog) on 12/4/10 (Saturday morning) intending to climb the SE ridge of Morning Star Peak.  Night prior to the climb was cold and clear.  Saturday was sunny and warmer.  The climber was off route and traveled up the mountain on a westerly direction north of the intended route.  Subject climbed up a ridge with a prominent gulley on climbers left.
The climber was reported overdue late Sunday morning.  Everett Mountain Rescue was paged out and responded.  Ground teams entered the field at dusk on Sunday.  Helicopter located tracks going up the mountain ending in a cliff band around the 3500 ft elevation level. Ground teams located tracks and followed same to the cliff band.  The tracks went into the gulley.  No tracks seen in gulley or elsewhere.  Small avalanches and rock falls heard in the valley and icefall observed into the gulley.  Helicopter searched gulley and adjacent slopes.  Ground teams searched ridge to north of gulley with voice, whistle, transceivers. Ground teams evacuated Sunday evening as area deemed unsafe for travel in the dark.  Ground teams inserted again early on Monday, followed tracks to last seen area and entered the gulley.  Obvious signs of an avalanche in the steep, confined gulley.  Voice, whistle, spot probed, and transceiver searched gulley.  2  K9  teams searching.  Subject located by ground team visual, and found dead mid-day on 12/6/2010 at 3100 ft elevation on skiers left side of gulley.  Subjectâ€™s dog located alive on surface 10 feet from subject.  Subject partially buried.

"Skiers 1 and 2 were in a safe spot and were able to witness the entire slide. For a couple of seconds it looked like [Skier 3] might be able to get out of it but a couple seconds later it was obvious that wasn't going to happen. He was totally consumed by the slide and we didn't see him again. The slide finished a little out of sight from where we were. We moved as fast as we could toward the slide with beacons out and in receive mode. When I got around the knoll I saw something I never would have imagined. [Skier 3] was STANDING in the middle of a ginormous debris field. Luck was on our side. He was little beaten up but was able to ski out under his own power."

location_name: Red Lake Peak, Carson Pass, CA
description: Party of two was descending on the north side of Red Lake Peak. The stopped at a safe spot above a choke point. As the first skier descended into the gully/choke point he triggered the slide and was swept into and over rocks and possible a small (30ft) cliff. He was buried under about three ft of debris with his poles sticking out.

A snowmobiler was caught and killed in an avalanche accident in an area known as Cherry Hill in the western Uinta Mountains. Staff from the Utah Avalanche Center visited the sight on Saturday, November 27th and will have a more detailed report available Sunday morning.

location_name: Wolf Creek Pass Ski Area, Glory Hole Point
description: A ski patroller conducting avalanche hazard mitigation at the Wolf Creek Pass ski area was caught buried and killed. The accident occurred within the ski area boundary, but before the resort was open to the public.

Four experienced backcountry skiers started skinning from Woods Creek Road right below the URAD mine tailings pile, near Butler Gulch. Skier 1 triggered an R3, D1 slab on the North facing, planar slope while traversing along the flat road cut below. The slide ran to the ground on approximately 5cm layer of cohesionless facets from the October storm cycle. Skier 1 was knocked off his feet and partially buried by debris in the bottom-left (facing uphill) edge of the runout zone. Skier 1’s face and front of torso remained clear, above the surface and was able to verbally confirm he was ok and not injured. Skier 2 assisted in digging out his feet and skies from the debris field. All members of the party were carrying beacon, shovel, and probe and have completed Avy I and II courses. This small, early season slide was a good reminder to all in the group that “If there is enough snow to ski, there is enough snow to slide” and highlighted the importance of safe terrain selection and situational awareness.
