At the same time, a member of the Buena Vista Search and Rescue Group was riding in the area with his son. They were part of a local snowmobile club rally and happened to ride over when they saw people on the debris. (The group from Colorado Springs was not a part of the rally.) They had a probe pole and a shovel. Shortly after, three local men rode up; they had a probe pole and several large grain-scoop shovels. They had been building a snowboarding jump. By now, the victim had been buried for about 10 minutes.

The rescue team member got out his rescue radio while his son started probing just uphill of the machine, and another man started probing below. Their only clue was the machine's ski sticking out from the snow. Within a minute, a probe hit the man buried under about 4 feet of snow. Digging uncovered a hand, then his face. He was found 6 feet uphill of the machine. Though he was not on his machine, he had not run more than a few steps when the avalanche struck.

The man was not breathing, and his color had turned "real blue." Another described his color as "purple." A sure sign that his body was not getting oxygen. The rescuers had just cleared snow from his chest and were ready to start artificial respiration when he started to breathe on his own. His color quickly returned to normal, and he slowly regained consciousness over the next five minutes. He was able to ride out on a snowmobile but spent the night in a local hospital. His only physical injury was a sore knee.

COMMENTS
This man was lucky, and he acknowledged so in the Denver Post story: "You can't get much luckier than I did." He was lucky that trained and equipped people were close by. He was lucky they found him so quickly, and he was lucky to have been buried in a favorable position. The man was found on his back with his face up. Victims found in this position are two times more likely to survive than those victims buried face down. When buried, a victim's body loses heat, especially around the face and head, causing the snow to melt. When buried supine with the face up, the face actually drops away from the snow, creating a small air space. If buried prone with face down, the air space is never created in front of the face as the head sinks into the snow. The fact that this man was not breathing means death was right around the corner.

This accident was typical of many snowmobile accidents. Not being equipped with avalanche rescue gear certainly put the group at a severe disadvantage, but this trait is common in most backcountry avalanche accidents, whether the victims were skiers, snowshoers, snowboarders, or snowmobilers. This accident shared several themes common to most snowmobile avalanche accidents, and sadly, similar to the fatal accident that occurred in Miner Basin a few weeks earlier (February 24, 2002). Snowmobile accidents frequently occur when more than one machine is on the slope. In both this accident and the one at Miner Basin, two riders were on this slope. In each case, the upper rider escaped, and the lower rider was buried, but don't read too much into this. These riders were lucky. The golden rule of traveling suspect slopes is "One at a time."

A more troubling theme is the dismissal of a significant danger clue: recent avalanches. Other avalanches had occurred along the same ridge, but the importance of their message was missed. Perhaps this was due to ignorance, arrogance, or overconfidence, or in some combination. Certainly, skiers, climbers, and snowboarders are just as guilty of this, too; however, it is common to hear of snowmobile accidents where someone in the group (and sometimes even the victim) triggered an avalanche earlier in the day or a day or two before in the same area. We hope to talk to the victim soon. I suspect that he and his companions that day had no or very little avalanche awareness training.

For all who travel in the backcountry, not getting caught in an avalanche requires avalanche education. This will overcome ignorance. Arrogance can be overcome by recognizing you can make a mistake, and overconfidence can be overcome by expecting the unexpected.

Surviving an avalanche, on the other hand, is a matter of luck. Invest in avalanche rescue gear, but travel as if you left it at home.

On Sunday afternoon, a 19-year-old male snowmobiler was buried and killed in an avalanche in northeastern Mesa County. [We had originally been told the accident occurred in northwest Pitkin County.] The victim was a member of a group of eight snowmobilers. The group carried no avalanche rescue gear and had to use branches and sticks to probe the snow. They used the windshields from their machines to dig the man free. The victim was found close to his nearly buried snowmobile after being buried for about 30 minutes. [Review of accidents shows that riders are nearly 2 times more likely to be buried than their snowmobile and are frequently found close to and typically a short distance uphill of their machine.] Efforts by companions to resuscitate their friend failed.

The group of eight snowmobilers had been high-marking in "Gully Bowl" earlier in the day before moving over to the small bowl/gully where the victim was caught and buried. This group of snowmobilers had triggered two small avalanches earlier in the day, before triggering the fatal avalanche. A small natural avalanche had also run in the same gully as the triggered avalanches. Unfortunately, the group had no avalanche awareness training and tragically failed to recognize the immediate threat and risk these avalanches foretold.

Some members of this group have been riding in this area since the mid-1990s.

location_name: Crystal Peak, northeast of Crested Butte
description:
SUMMARY
At about 2:45 on a sunny Wednesday afternoon, a 39-year-old Alamosa man was buried and killed in a small avalanche he likely triggered on the south side of Crystal Peak (12,777 feet), not far from the Friends Hut in the Elk Mountains of Gunnison County. The man was skiing 10 to 20 minutes ahead of some friends. No one witnessed the avalanche, but even the very quick and speedy rescue was too long in coming.

ACCIDENT
The group and the victim were a cautious bunch, concerned about avalanches. They had already been at the Friends Hut for a couple of days after skiing over from Ashcroft via a night at the Green-Wilson Hut on Sunday. They reached the Friends Hut early Monday afternoon after traversing Pearl Pass. That afternoon, several did some skiing nearby.

On Tuesday, the group skied the trees on Hunter Hill, a bit over a mile southeast of the hut and a little over a mile south of Crystal Peak. The skiing was not very good because of the shallow, weak depth-hoar snow cover. (Poor backcountry skiing because of shallow snow and depth hoar has been a common complaint voiced by backcountry skiers in most mountain areas this winter.) One member in the party described the snow conditions as "soft - hard - soft - hard." The snow cover and skiing were unpredictable; sometimes the snow easily supported a skier's weight, and sometimes a skier would sink to the ground in sugar snow. While skiing that day, the victim recognized and spoke about "suspect [avalanche] slopes," and he and his friends carefully avoided some slopes. The victim and friends "knew enough to be worried" about the snow and avalanche conditions.

Tuesday night (February 5), the winds increased, causing blowing snow and temperatures to steadily warm. Wednesday morning dawned sunny and warm; it was a balmy 25 degrees at the hut. It would be a great day to climb Crystal Peak and check out the sights. Concerned about avalanche conditions, the group even practiced with their avalanche transceivers before setting out. After the practice session, four members headed off to Crystal Peak while one stayed behind to enjoy the sun.
The group reached the summit and started down the south ridge. The victim, traveling alone and in front of the others, stopped and waited for his friends. A lunch stop was called. After a short break, the victim who had been waiting the longest decided to continue down while his friends continued their lunch. Perhaps he had become a bit chilled waiting in the slight breeze.

RESCUE
After being out of sight for about 20 minutes, two men went to "check" on their friend. They traveled some distance before discovering the avalanche. The pair started a beacon search and quickly located the victim in about 3 minutes. The burial time was estimated at about 20 minutes, and resuscitation efforts failed. The victim was buried near the high end of the debris under about 4 feet of snow. He died from asphyxiation. Realizing their friend was dead, the men regrouped at the hut. There, they used an emergency radio to contact the Mt. Crested Butte Police Department.

The following day, rescuers from the Crested Butte Mountain Rescue Team headed to the site. On the way in, they met four of the group who were headed out. One member stayed behind at the hut to guide rescuers to the avalanche. The rescue team reached the avalanche in mid-afternoon and started the evacuation. After an arduous evacuation, the rescuers reached the trailhead early the next afternoon (Friday).

COMMENTS
This accident resulted in more questions than answers, and unfortunately, we will never know all the answers. As mentioned earlier, the group and the victim were avalanche-aware and cautious, but for some reason that Wednesday afternoon, the victim chose to cross a suspect slope. Perhaps the smooth, recently wind-drifted snow looked much more inviting than the surrounding wind-scoured snow. Unfortunately, it was the wrong place to go. The slab may have been more sensitive to triggered release than similar slabs in other aspects. This slab was likely warmer.

The blowing snow and warming temperatures the night before the accident are an interesting sequence of events. Blowing snow is a regular event at the higher elevations; however, a significant warm-up is less common, but a combination of the two is unusual. The blowing snow resulted in a fresh slab of relatively warm snow. In addition, the slope also faced southwest, receiving plenty of afternoon sunshine, even for early February. How can this be bad when generally we think of warm new snow as snow that will settle and stabilize quickly? Compared to colder snow, warmer snow makes it easier for a skier to affect weak layers buried below.

The weight of a person penetrates deeper into a warm slab than a cold slab. In other words, warm slabs allow the weight to be transferred more easily to buried weak layers. Experienced ski patrollers and avalanche forecasters know that avalanches can be triggered more easily after sun or warm air has warmed a cold slab. The process is not understood very well, but it might help explain what happened. It is important to remember when dealing with dry-snow avalanches to never base your entire stability evaluation on temperature alone. In this case, other more important factors were evident: a fresh slab, a steep slope, and a weak layer of depth hoar. To learn more about the effect of temperatures on snow, pick up a copy of Bruce Tremper's book Staying Alive in Avalanche Terrain.

We will never know why the victim was traveling alone. Friends described the victim as "very competitive" and physically "very strong." Perhaps a friendly but anonymous rivalry kept the victim inspired to stay out in front, or perhaps he just enjoyed the solitude. Regardless of the reasons, when one travels alone, there is no margin for error. Had he stayed back with his friends, the outcome might have been very different.

On Friday afternoon, a 67-year-old man was found buried in a very, very small loose-snow avalanche just beyond the boundary of the Aspen Highlands ski area. This unwitnessed and very tragic incident demonstrates how a series of unintended mishaps can lead to an accident, and also how a very small loose-snow avalanche can be deadly, especially for a lone person.

The victim was skiing with friends when he became separated. His friends waited at the bottom, but when he failed to arrive, they retraced their route. Failing to find their friend, they reported him missing to the ski patrol. Shortly afterward, a ski patroller spotted the victim's ski in the snow a short distance below a ski run.
Just beyond the ski area boundary rope, the man had triggered a very narrow 4 to 6-foot-wide loose-snow avalanche. He was carried a short distance down slope and buried under 18 inches of snow. The corner's preliminary report tells that the man died from asphyxiation. He was buried for about one hour.

The accident was the result of several unintended mishaps. This victim did not duck under the boundary rope and leave the ski run on purpose. The corner found the man had suffered a "high-impact" fall that incapacitated the victim and caused him to slide off the trail. He narrowly missed trees and landed in a very small pocket of undisturbed faceted sugar-snow. The resulting loose-snow avalanche was likely one of the smallest fatal avalanches in Colorado. The avalanche released just over 2 feet deep and to the ground, but was only a narrow ribbon of snow 4 to 6 feet wide and traveled only 130 feet (slope distance). This avalanche is classified as a L-AS-1-G.

Tragically, in this accident, a series of minor events: becoming separated from friends, falling hard, sliding off the run, and being alone, resulted in a fatal outcome. This accident demonstrates that even small avalanches can be just as deadly as large avalanches. Incapacitated from his fall, the man could not help himself. Had he still been with someone, he would have survived the avalanche. This accident also highlights a snowpack problem that affects most mountain areas at lower elevations.
This season's light snowfall has resulted in a shallow and very weak snow cover. At lower elevations (below treeline)--in many mountain areas and including the Aspen area--the snowcover is composed of depth hoar, or advanced faceted, sugar-like snow. In these areas, there is no slab or cohesive layer of snow, only sugar snow from top to bottom. This cohesionless, faceted snowcover is weak and may slough off steep slopes when pushed. Ski patrols across the state have been busy trying to strengthen this weak snow by compaction or by sloughing it off steep areas, but this snow is practically everywhere. With that said, loose-snow or point-release avalanches seldom cause serious problems. In fact, in our CAIC publication Avalanche Wise (CGS Special Publication 48), we wrote "...they are usually small in size and seldom cause injury or damage." Fatal loose-snow avalanches in Colorado are rare.

Prior to this accident, there had been only one other fatal avalanche accident in Colorado since 1950 involving loose snow. (One in 144 fatal avalanche accidents have involved loose snow; in five additional accidents, the type of avalanche was not known.) That accident occurred when a small cornice block fell, triggering a wet loose-snow avalanche in August of 1972, killing one hiker.

SUMMARY
Early Wednesday afternoon, two local Boulder County men were skiing the open slope above Yankee Doodle Lake when they triggered a sizable hard-slab avalanche. The avalanche struck the ice-covered lake and shattered the ice, dumping both men into the water. The pair were skilled and avalanche-savvy backcountry skiers who were well-equipped for a day in the mountains. One man died (drowned?). His friend escaped, but unable to find his missing partner, he hiked back to the Eldora ski area to get help.

This was the men's third day in a row on this slope, where two days earlier they had enjoyed terrific powder skiing. Before starting their descent, the pair dug a snow pit. Apparently satisfied with what they had found, they agreed to ski short distances one at a time, taking turns watching each other while the other would wait at a "safe" spot. The first man (survivor) skied a short distance to a flatter, bench area and traversed toward some rocks to avoid a much steeper cliff area. He glanced back over his shoulder and spotted his friend who had just started down. He then realized the entire slope was moving. The avalanche left both men in Yankee Doodle Lake.

The survivor ended up nearly in the middle of the lake, approximately 190 feet from shore. Packed in shattered ice and water, he struggled to the shore. Yells for his friend brought no response, and he could not detect a signal from his friend's avalanche beacon. His waterlogged cell phone did not work, so he set out for help. He hiked down the Jenny Creek trail for the 5 miles to Eldora Mountain Resort.

RESCUE
The Eldora Ski Patrol responded first, followed by members of the Rocky Mountain Rescue Group. Arriving as darkness fell, the hasty search was organized. Searchers tried to detect a beacon signal but could not, so probe poles were used to search likely burial areas. More rescuers arrived, including avalanche rescue dogs. The rescuers could not search the shattered ice and water until later that evening when trained dive-rescuers arrived with specialized rubber suits. After 2300 hours that evening, a dive-rescue team member searching the refreezing surface detected a signal. The missing man was found 91 feet offshore in the frozen snow, ice, and water.

COMMENTS
These men were smart and savvy backcountry skiers who were doing things by the book, yet still got into trouble. At the time of the accident (and in the days before the accident), we were rating the backcountry avalanche danger in all mountain areas at CONSIDERABLE. Triggered avalanche releases were probable, and natural avalanches were possible on northwest through northeast to southeast-facing slopes near and above tree line. The avalanche the men triggered occurred on an east-southeast to southeast-facing slope at tree line.

Before rushing to judgment, remember that both men were backcountry and avalanche smart. They had the right equipment and knowledge to be out in the terrain, snow, and weather conditions. Boulder County Sheriff George Epp said it well in the Daily Camera newspaper (11/30/2001, page 5A) when he was quoted "If you try to get a lesson out of this...the mountains can be dangerous no matter how prepared you are."

This is the first Colorado avalanche death in Colorado in the 2001-2002 winter, and the second in the United States. Incidents where avalanche victims are swept into water and drowned are uncommon but not unheard of. In 1978, at Twin Lakes, California, a county snowplow and a pickup with two occupants were swept into the unfrozen Lower Twin Lake. The snowplow operator swam to shore. Twenty minutes later, a motorist stopped by the earlier avalanche climbed onto the debris, where he was caught by a second avalanche and swept into the lake. All three motorists drowned. In 1981, near Elko, Nevada, a snowmobiler was caught and swept into an ice-covered lake and drowned.

A 40-year-old snowboarder was climbing the east face of South Diamond Peak at Cameron Pass. He was wearing snowshoes with his board in his backpack. Once he reached the bench at timberline, he began climbing up the main gully. Two other snowshoers (from Minnesota) were standing on the bench and filming the lone climber with their camcorder. They stopped filming when they thought he had reached the ridge, which happened to be 2 minutes before the avalanche, and they began walking away from the slope. At 11:55 am, the climber triggered a large avalanche when he was about 200 feet below the ridge, and about 40 vertical feet below the fracture line.

The avalanche came down with a large powder cloud, and debris filled the bench and flowed over the bench (which is about 400 feet across and slopes gently) into the timber. The debris overran the spot the two snowshoers had been standing on two minutes earlier and stopped a few feet short of where they were standing. Meanwhile, Dan Myer of Fort Collins was driving toward the pass and saw the avalanche. He parked and began climbing up the lower track toward the bench and avalanche debris area. He met the two snowshoers, learned someone was in the avalanche, and began a beacon search. He searched for 45 minutes without success. Someone stopped a CDOT truck, and the Jackson and Larimer County Sheriffs were notified. The avalanche was just inside the Jackson County line.

Sometime after 3 pm, rescuers saw the tip of a snowboard sticking from the snow and located the victim, who had died. He had been carried about 500 vertical feet down a sustained 37-degree slope and was buried about 1 foot deep.

This accident occurred very close to where a backcountry skier was killed on December 14, 1999. We will post more as details become available.

On Sunday (12/3) afternoon, two backcountry skiers triggered a sizable hard slab avalanche off the southeast shoulder of Point 12,805 in Herman Gulch, several miles east of the Eisenhower-Johnson Tunnel. The couple had started down skiing the center of the slope. The man went first and skied partway down before turning off to his right. The woman followed, and when she was near where he had cut right, the entire slope collapsed. The man was able to escape to the side; however, the woman was swept down. Fortunately, she stayed on top of a block of snow and remained on the surface. Rescuers met the couple as they descended back to the highway.

Though no other avalanches were visible in the immediate area of Herman Gulch, just a few miles west, a dozen avalanches had occurred on and around Loveland Pass since Thursday, the 30th.

At 1343 hours on Saturday (12/02) afternoon, members of the Alpine Rescue Team--who had been participating in an avalanche awareness training on Loveland Pass--watched 2 lucky hikers trigger a combination soft and hard slab near the summit of Loveland Pass. The two men were glissading (sitting) when the snow fractured and swept them down for a short and bumpy ride. The pair were lucky the snow did not sweep them into the large rocks near the toe of the debris. Both men remained on the surface and walked down to the highway.

Approximately a dozen avalanches had occurred on and around Loveland Pass since Thursday, the 30th. All slides were clearly visible on Saturday. The men had no avalanche awareness training.

This accident was never formally reported, as the group of skiers affected their own rescue after the ski area had closed for the day. Sadly, one 31-year-old man died several days later in a Denver hospital from internal injuries suffered when he was swept into a tree and rocks.

SUMMARY
A group of four young men (in their 20s) was visiting the Arapahoe Basin Ski Area when they decided to venture out of the area in pursuit of untracked powder. The men were skiing out-of-area in an area known as Marjorie's Bowl, just north-northeast of the ski area. Having already made one run in the area earlier in the afternoon, the group headed back to the bowl just before the lifts closed.

Two men had already skied down when the victim started down. The fourth skier started soon afterwards and likely triggered a shallow but sizable soft-slab avalanche. The victim heard the moving snow and tried to ski away from the moving snow, but was hit from behind and swept into a small tree and then into some rocks. The fourth skier was also swept down and injured when he collided with some rocks.

The two injured men were assisted by their friends back to the ski area. The group arrived long after the lifts had closed and everybody had gone home. While returning to Denver, the condition of the most seriously injured man (Skier 3) worsened. His friends took him to a Denver-area hospital, where he was admitted with serious internal injuries and a head injury. Skier 4 was treated for a shoulder/arm injury. Not wanting to draw attention to themselves, the men told the hospital staff that the two were injured "playing ski football" after colliding with a tree.

Two days later, Skier 3 died from internal injuries.

COMMENTS
This accident highlights the serious consequences faced by all skiers and riders who leave a ski area boundary. Often, those with the least amount of training and knowledge suffer the worst.

Much about this accident is still unknown, but friends and family of the deceased have told us some details.

The victim had moved from California to Colorado a few months earlier and was an avid skier. All four men were good skiers and had no (or very little) avalanche awareness training.

On the morning of the 21st, up to 6 inches of new, cold snow was reported in the Loveland Pass area. Reduction work by the ski patrols at both Arapahoe Basin and Loveland Basin Ski Areas produced minimal results, though Breckenridge did report several sizable avalanches triggered by explosives. However, conditions within a ski area are usually very dissimilar to conditions beyond the ski-area boundary, even when separated by only a 1/4-inch strand of rope. This group knew of the area's boundary ropes and closure signs.

By late afternoon on the 21st, the warming temperatures and sunshine softened the new snow, causing a loss in strength. By the group's second run on the northerly-facing slope, the snow had reached a critical point and could not support the additional weight of the skiers. In the spring (and early summer), fresh snow and sunshine can lead to short-term instability lasting from a few hours to perhaps a day. Usually, the most unstable slopes are those freshly snow-covered slopes that face northeast to east to south to west; however, by late in the day, even the northerly-facing slopes can become dangerous.

It may seem surprising that a serious avalanche accident could occur so close to a ski area and go unobserved. However, four factors contributed to this accident going unnoticed.

First, the avalanche could not be seen from the ski area, though the slide could likely have been seen from Loveland Pass. Second, the avalanche was triggered late in the day, and lengthening shadows likely masked the avalanche and debris area. A third factor was a vigorous spring storm that developed on the 22nd, burying any sign of the avalanche under a foot of new snow. Fourth and lastly, the men were able to affect their own rescue and did not want word of their trouble out.

Though their lack of knowledge and some questionable judgments contributed to this accident, the men did an excellent job to evacuate and care for their injured friends. It is doubtful that even a speedy rescue by the ski patrol would have changed the outcome of this accident. What is a bit disturbing is the reason why the men did not seek outside help or report the accident: their fear of potential prosecution and media attention. The future will bring more avalanche and mountaineering accidents, but when people are afraid to seek help because of potential prosecution, media attention, and/or the threat of being charged for rescue, only the victim will suffer.

ACCIDENT
Four skiers and two snowboarders were involved in this party. Three of these skiers (Rick, John, and Steve) had been skiing the Highlands Ridge backcountry for much of the season. Mike was a less frequent skier but was 'training' for a Haute Route trip in late March. The other 2 snowboarders (Brian and Justin) were planning on their own trip to a part of Maroon Bowl, but met up with the first 4 and decided to go along.

Aspen Highlands maintains an open boundary policy whereby any skier can access the National Forest where it abuts the opened ski area. They passed through the backcountry access point on Highland Ridge and continued to Highland Peak. The route they were planning on skiing is just south of Highland Peak on the west side of the ridge. It is a very steep line that has seldom been skied since the open boundary policy began three years ago.

The plan formulated was for each skier in turn to ski the entire path down to the main basin, where several other paths join and the pitch abruptly mellows to about 15 degrees. Justin boarded first and, after arriving in the runout, went to some trees below a south aspect pitch. Mike skied next straight down the gully but stopped before reaching the flats and stayed in the main track, visible to Justin. Able to see only Justin from the top, Rick waited to see Mike. When he did not, after some time, he assumed that he had found a safe area in some trees to the skier's left. Rick skied next, but partway down, began to break into the trees looking for Mike. He ended up crossing a slight ridge and skiing a south aspect into the basin. Brian left next and skied about 10 to 15 turns, breaking out to the skier's right where he felt he could see the whole pitch better. He took cover under a large rock band. Steve skied a few turns and broke out left to cover under another large rock outcrop.

As John began to ski, probably only 3 turns in, the others noticed him stumble, and John yelled 'avalanche'. He had triggered a slab about 1 foot deep and was riding in it. John was attempting to stay upright. After about 100 vertical feet, the slab released to the ground about 4 feet deep.

John was last seen tumbling in the flow. Brian reported that as the avalanche went by the there was the sound of rocks rolling in the avalanche, similar to rocks being tumbled in the spring runoff of a river. In the run out, Justin saw the avalanche coming and yelled to Rick and Mike. Both Rick and Justin began moving diagonally down in opposite directions to escape the flow. Rick reported that 'the sky went dark, the wind picked up, and I thought it was over'. Both were able to outrun the debris flow. Justin was the only one of the party who saw Mike hit in the track. The debris rapidly decelerated and spread after reaching the bottom of the track

RESCUE
Brian and Steve, after yelling for John, began to move down the path, which the avalanche had polished smooth. They had several large rocky areas to contend with to get to the debris. Their beacons were on receive the whole trip down.

Justin, well below the debris by this point, decided that the trip back up in snowboard boots would be too long. With no idea of who was left standing, he went for help.
After the powder cloud cleared, Rick reported dead silence, and he, too, did not know where anyone was. He re-skinned and returned to the debris pile.

The time of the avalanche was approximately 12:15. Justin reached the Maroon Creek Road and reported the avalanche to the T-Lazy-Seven guest ranch at about 12:45. They, in turn, notified the ski patrol and the sheriff's department. The patrol responded for the county sheriff with a hasty team of three people. Little information was available other than the number in the party and the size of the avalanche, and Justin was sure that the avalanche caught at least Mike. The others were only sure that John had been caught. Rick arrived on the debris at the same time as Steve and Brian. They all began picking up two signals, which confirmed that Mike was also involved. They had some trouble initially with the double signals, but eventually were able to pinpoint and, with some probing, located the first body, which they dug up. Mike's lips were white and his face was completely blue. After clearing his airway, they were able to find no signs of pulse or breathing, and in the correct triage fashion, turned his beacon off and began to search for John.

They quickly were able to pinpoint, then they probed and dug out John, who was at approximately the same elevation and within 100 feet horizontally from Mike. John had obvious signs of trauma. They could not detect any pulse and did not attempt CPR. After marking the bodies and reactivating the beacons, they skied towards Maroon Creek Road.

Virtually simultaneously with their arrival on the road (where ski patrol was waiting), the hasty team reached the debris. They did nothing more than confirm the identities, mark the locations, and take some coroner's photos. They then proceeded to Maroon Creek Road.

Mountain Rescue Aspen recovered the bodies the next day.

COMMENTS
This was a very experienced and equipped backcountry skiing group. There is likely no one more experienced in the terrain outside Highlands than Rick, John, and Steve. They had been digging snowpits all year and had begun skiing on Thanksgiving Day 1999 (with 15cm total snow at Highlands). Mike's choice of a safe area is the only error one could point out in the technique of the entire party. They all knew the risks and rewards of where they were skiing. The self-rescue technique was flawless, and all kept their composure during adversity. This accident serves to underscore the inherent danger in backcountry skiing on steep avalanche terrain in Colorado, especially on steep northwest aspect slopes.

SUMMARY
A small avalanche buried and killed a well-known Snowmass Village man on the backside of Aspen Mountain. The victim had spent a great day skiing with his girlfriend and other friends in the Hurricane Bowl area near Little Annie Basin.

ACCIDENT
Toward the end of the afternoon, the girlfriend realized she had forgotten her backpack at the top of Aspen Mountain, a couple of miles away. The plan was for her to snowmobile back to the top of the ski area to retrieve her pack while her boyfriend skied down to the cars. They planned to rendezvous at the parking area between 1630 and 1700 hrs. He never arrived.

The victim's last run was down the upper portion of Hurricane Bowl and then ended in a terrain trap about one-half mile above the parking area. Skiing alone, he triggered a small avalanche in a narrow, steep-sided gully.

RESCUE
From the parking lot, the girlfriend and a friend snowmobiled back to the top of the slope, intending to find and follow the victim's tracks. Along the way, they met an Aspen Mountain ski patroller who was snowmobiling home from work. The three rounded up one other friend to help search and set out to find the tracks.

One man followed the victim's tracks into a narrow gully with a steep north-facing side. The tracks disappeared into avalanche debris. The other three approached from the bottom. When they realized what had happened, they instructed the victim's girlfriend to get additional help while the other three started the search. The victim's girlfriend called Pitkin County Sheriff's Office at 1745 hours.

A beacon search was unsuccessful, so the trio started probing the center of the gully. Standing three-across the trio could easily cover the narrow gully bottom. They made a strike after 20 minutes of probing.

The victim was found upside down, in an almost headstand position. His head was buried under 6 feet of snow. CPR was attempted without success. The victim's mouth and nose were plugged with snow.

By the time Mountain Rescue Aspen members arrived at the staging area, the man's body had been found and was being brought down to the parking area. By that time, it was dark and snowing moderately.

COMMENTS
The narrow gully was a classic terrain trap. The 37-year-old victim was an expert backcountry skier with at least some avalanche awareness training. This season, he had skied through the gully several times before. The route was logical for any skier or rider, especially in a dry season. It was an easy, direct run to the parking lot, and it had snow.

Snow conditions were unstable, and the victim knew that two days earlier, a skier in Little Annie Basin had been buried in an avalanche and was rescued by companions without injury. That accident occurred on terrain similar to where this fatal accident occurred. It is uncertain if the victim or the victim's friends encountered any obvious signs of instability, but for some reason (or reasons), he chose to ski into an obvious terrain trap during a time of great instability.

In hindsight, it is easy to say that better route finding, not traveling alone, and carrying avalanche rescue gear could have prevented this accident. However, the root of this accident is a more important issue: "Why did this experienced skier let himself into a dangerous trap?" At the time, he was not carrying avalanche rescue gear. The implication is that he was not expecting trouble.

Overconfidence and/or a lack of situational awareness are two key factors that lead to skilled people getting into trouble. This accident was a case where poor judgment overcame experience.
Too little information available at this time (January 25, 2000). The accident occurred about 1 mile west of the Arapahoe Basin Ski Area in an area known as "The Steep Gullies" or "The Beavers".
Too little information available at this time (January 23, 2000). The Jones Pass area is a popular backcountry area southwest of Berthoud Pass. The accident did not occur in Butler Gulch.

ACCIDENT
On the morning of December 21, a 25-year-old Broomfield man told friends he was going backcountry skiing, but he never told them where he was headed. A few days earlier, on the 19th, the victim had told his sister in Illinois he was going to climb a 14er, but again he failed to say where. Friends and co-workers reported him missing on the 23rd. On the 24th, the Broomfield Police Department issued a state-wide missing persons report. Later on Christmas Eve the Summit County Sheriffs Office on a routine patrol at the Quandary Peak trailhead parking lot located his vehicle. At 14,265 feet, Quandary Peak is a popular "14er" for winter climbers and skiers. Located at the south end of the Tenmile Range, the summit is about 6.5 miles SSW of Breckenridge.

RESCUE
On Christmas morning, the Summit County Rescue Group mobilized a search effort. Five avalanches had spilled off the Southeast side of Quandary Peak, but lady luck was with searchers that morning. Very early in the operation a searcher happened across a tiny torn piece of a topographic map. Moving 100 yards further upslope, he came across another small piece of a topographic map. Minutes later, they spotted the victim further upslope. They found the man buried in the avalanche debris. A leg protruded from the snow. The victim had died of massive trauma.

COMMENTS
The victim frequently traveled solo in the mountains, but in this situation, a partner would not have made any difference in the outcome of this accident. In fact, had a partner been traveling with the victim it is likely there would have been two fatalities. This accident could have only been prevented by better judgment. Better judgment to avoid all steep slopes during a time when very unstable snow conditions existed. The victim's level of avalanche training and/or whether he had heard a CAIC report is unknown. The traditional route up Quandary Peak is an easy ascent and descent. The route is very straightforward and avoids most dangerous avalanche slopes. Even during periods of significant avalanche danger, the route can be followed without problem with careful route selection. We will never know exactly where the victim was when the avalanche occurred or what he was thinking prior to the avalanche. Though this accident was not witnessed, reasonable inferences can be made about what happened.

The victim was found at the bottom of a very steep and rocky gully. This gully would have been a poor ski choice even in the best of weather and stability conditions. The route is well east of the summit and has two significant cliff bands that are seldom if ever covered by snow. With the cliff bands in the gully it is very unlikely the man was trying to ascend the gully. He likely was crossing near the steep slopes above the gully when it avalanched. It is unknown if the man summited, but we doubt he did.
While it is possible that the slope released naturally, this scenario is unlikely. A natural release would imply the victim was low on the slope. This setting would have taken the victim far off the route. Also relatively few natural releases were reported from around Summit County on the 21st and 22nd though a large cycle of natural releases did occur on the 23rd. The other four avalanches on Quandary likely ran that day. Also on the 21st and 22nd ski patrollers reported slab avalanches were easy to triggered from ski pressure. Most likely, the victim triggered his own avalanche.

Both of the victim's alpine touring ski boots were stripped from his feet. Boots only come off a victim when they are worn very loosely. Many people loosen their boots for ascending, but most people seldom ever wear loose boots for a descent. With loose boots it seems reasonable the victim was traversing across the top of the gully when he triggered the avalanche. Though this line of ascent would be off the established route, it would not be unreasonable.

The weather on the 21st was nasty with light snow and strong winds, but visibility was okay. That day above treeline ski patrollers around Summit County reported fair visibility. Occasionally, brief white-outs lasting a few seconds would obscure visibility, but landmarks along the route would have been visible and easy to follow. To avoid the wind the victim may have purposely veered off-route to travel in the sheltered lee of the ridge. This would have placed the victim on relatively steep terrain. Foot travel would have been easy on the hard snow. Much of this snow was relatively fresh and stable. It would have only been on this steep slope for a few weeks, so it had not had the time to weaken into faceted sugar-snow grains. But like a mine field, there were pockets of older snow on the same slope that had already weakened into sugar snow. When the victim unknowingly traveled across such a pocket, he triggered the hard slab and was swept down the mountain to his death.

Traveling alone in the high mountains during storms can be a very rewarding experience. It is a way to improve one's comfort level in difficult settings, but it is not a time to push one's limits. Obviously the consequences of any mistake can be severe or as they were in this case: fatal. Risk can be reduced significantly by exercising a large margin of safety. The judgment that allows us to set and operate within an appropriate margin of safety comes from experience. At times, gaining experience in the high mountains can be a risky proposition. Usually, when we make mistakes, the mountains are forgiving and retreat home with a lesson learned. In this accident, the mountains were unforgiving.

ACCIDENT
A small avalanche buried and killed a 21-year-old CSU student Tuesday afternoon near Cameron Pass in the Medicine Bow Mountains of Northern Colorado. Cameron Pass is a popular backcountry ski/riding area along SH14 about 50 miles west of Fort Collins. The victim was with two snowboarding friends when the avalanche occurred at about 1330. The victim, on telemark skis, was "skinning up" toward the south summit of the Diamond Peaks while his friends waited lower down on the peak. They did not see him get caught, but started to search after they saw (or heard) the avalanche. They were joined briefly by two other friends, who then left to get help. With no last seen area, the remaining pair could only dig with their snowboards in randomly selected spots. After making sure help was on the way, the other two returned to the accident site, but then left to guide additional rescuers back to the site.

RESCUE
The Larimer County Sheriff's Department was notified of the accident about one hour later. While search and rescue team members responded, several "forest service" (not sure if USFS or Colorado State Forest) employees searched some of the debris with probe poles. The search was postponed shortly after darkness due to poor visibility and additional wind loading.

The search resumed early Wednesday morning with four trained avalanche rescue dogs. The man's body was located about 10 minutes after the search started. He was buried very close to the surface; a hand and foot were within 6 inches of the surface.

A 31-year-old Telluride man was buried and killed on Wednesday afternoon near Ophir in southwestern Colorado. The man was skiing alone at the time of the avalanche; however, he had been with friends but stopped to wait for some others.

Eight skiers in two groups were descending the Magnolia slide path in the Ophir valley. The victim was in a group of five, but decided to wait for the other three skiers. The four skiers in the first group continued down to pick up their shuttle vehicle. It seems the victim headed down alone and triggered the soft slab avalanche.

The four skiers now at their vehicle saw the powder cloud, but at first, thought it was only blowing snow. When they arrived at the bottom of the path they realized what had happened. They feared the worst, thinking the remaining four had been buried. The San Miguel Sheriff's Office was notified at 1250 hours.

They immediately started a beacon search and picked up only one signal. As they approached the signal they spotted a hand sticking out from the snow. They quickly uncovered the man and started cardio-pulmonary resuscitation. About this time the other skiers arrived and confirmed only one had been buried.

Members of the San Miguel County Search and Rescue and the Telluride Ski Patrol responded. The rescuers continued CPR but without success. The victim was declared dead at the scene. An autopsy is scheduled to determine if the victim died of suffocation or trauma.

location_name: St. Mary's Glacier, northwest of Idaho Springs
description:
SUMMARY
A lucky backcountry skier survived a short burial at St. Mary's Glacier by the quick action of a couple of avalanche-savvy snowboarders. At about 10:30 AM, two skiers stood above the steep slopes above St. Mary's Lake. The first skier ventured onto the slope, and when he made his first turn, he triggered a shallow soft-slab avalanche. (He was probably carried over the cliff band seen in the photo.)

About 150 yards to the south of the avalanche, a couple of well-equipped snowboarders had just ridden down along the edge of the trees and were getting ready to hike back up hill for another run. Equipped with transceivers and shovels, the pair had decided not to tackle the glacier area but to ride in the less-steep terrain just south of the lake. They saw the avalanche and watched the skier disappear under the snow just before the snow quickly piled up at the base of the steep slope.

With a good last-seen-area noted, the snowboarders quickly rode down through the trees toward the lake and started a shallow traverse toward the debris. Getting to the flats at the lake, the pair ran the last few yards onto the debris. At the last seen area, they found the victim's glasses and quickly started digging.

They picked the right spot and soon hit the buried man. His face was uncovered within 5 minutes after the slide. The skier was buried face down with his head under about one foot of snow. His legs and feet were even deeper. (Looking at the hole, his feet were buried about 4 feet). The victim's friend carefully skied down the bed surface of the avalanche to help get his friend out. While the man was being dug out, the Clear County Sheriff's Office was notified, and local rescue teams responded.

Battered but okay, the man and his friend quietly retreated to their vehicle and avoided rescuers and questions. Fortunately, one of the rescuers called our office to report the accident. (Thank you!)

COMMENTS
Though no new snow had fallen in the past several days, conditions were ripe for an avalanche on this particular slope. Nature provided fair warning. The slope immediately to the north--the glacier proper--had recently avalanched; the fracture lines and debris were plainly visible. This avalanche likely released over the weekend as only a portion of the fracture line was covered by freshly drifted snow. Most of the fracture lines and old bed surface snow were obvious. This recent slide occurred on an identical slope as to elevation, aspect, and slope angle.

Certainly, a recent avalanche is the best clue of avalanche danger, but there was another clue--though an often neglected clue--of danger: a sun-warmed slope. Of course, the sun warms slopes in the springtime, but the avalanche danger increases when there is fresh/recent snow, often topping an icy melt-freeze crust, on steep, sun-exposed slopes. In Colorado, these sun-warmed slopes are more of an avalanche problem in the spring and early summer than in mid-winter. Here is why sun-warmed slopes can be avalanche-problem slopes.

Spring and early summer snowstorms can still deposit cold, winter-like snow. If this new snow falls onto an old, icy sun crust, the new snow tends not to adhere to this crust. While snow is a lousy thermal conductor, the sun's energy can quickly warm the top several inches of the new snow. This warming occurs first in the early mornings on steep east-facing slopes, and the warming on other aspects from south through west as the sun tracks across the sky. As the snow warms, the slab softens, and stresses caused by gravity between the warmer surface snow and the colder sub-surface snow increase. As these stresses approach the snow's strength, the slab becomes more unstable. When stresses are equal or exceed the strength, avalanches result, or avalanches can release even sooner when the additional stress caused by a person tips this tenuous balance. Be wary of fresh snow over old crusts on steep slopes bathed in bright sunshine, even early in the morning. The fresh snow does not need to become wet for avalanches to occur.

One last thing...this buried skier was very lucky to be rescued so quickly. He and his friend did not carry avalanche rescue equipment. Had the two avalanche-ready snowboarders not been so close by, this story may have ended tragically. It is also remarkable that he was able to walk away from this avalanche after tumbling through the rocks. He cheated death and walked away...he ought to buy a lottery ticket, soon!

Cumberland Pass is located about 25 air miles (ENE) of Gunnison in the Sawatch Range. From the north, snowmobilers can access the pass from Taylor Park Reservoir via Tin Cup, while from the south, access is from Pitkin.

A group of 6 Western State students (Gunnison) were using snowmobiles to access the backcountry skiing on Cumberland Pass (12,020 feet) in eastern Gunnison County. Two of the group waited at a cabin not far from the pass while the other four continued on. While towing skiers up to the pass, the snowmobile became stuck about 3/4 of the way up the slope. A skier continued up to the top while the other three worked at freeing the stuck machine. The skier skied down to his friends, and as he approached the small group, the entire slope fractured and released.

The four men raced to the trees, but only the skier reached the trees. He survived; his friends did not.

About 20 minutes after the group first split, one of the men at the cabin headed uphill and noticed the avalanche. He returned to the cabin for his friend, and both men returned to the avalanche. Once at the site, one man started to search while the other left to get help. He drove a snowmobile the 8 to 10 miles back to Pitkin and reported the avalanche at about 1415 hours.

At the accident site, one man, a skier, was found buried. He had been buried next to a tree that provided an air space. His companion and other rescuers used transceivers to locate the other three. The first rescuers from Pitkin arrived at 1445. By 1500 hours, the first victim was uncovered, and the other two were uncovered by 1515 hours. All three were buried between 3 and 5 feet deep.

This is the worst avalanche accident in Colorado since 3 backcountry skiers were buried and killed on Pearl Pass on January 10, 1988.

Not far from Pitkin, Colorado's worst-ever single avalanche killed 13 people at the town of Woodstock (West of the Alpine Tunnel) on March 10, 1884.

A well-equipped group of 9 snowmobilers was following the Hidden Valley Trail on the north side of the Grand Mesa when one man triggered a small hard-slab avalanche. The group was traveling along a bench at about 10,600 feet when the victim triggered the avalanche from below, like pulling the log out of the bottom of a wood pile. His companions quickly organized a rescue and used their transceivers to find the man. He was buried about 15 minutes under 5 feet of snow.

The backcountry avalanche danger was rated an overall MODERATE with pockets of CONSIDERABLE on steep N-E facing aspects 35 degrees and steeper both above and below treeline. Triggered avalanches by backcountry travelers were possible to probable.

Between 1500 and 1530 hours on Friday, two local men left the Aspen Highlands ski area to ski the backcountry below the ski area's Steeple Chase terrain. The men passed through a US Forest Service Gate and intended to ski down to the Castle Creek road, a popular "last run" (no pun intended) for many adventurous skiers and snowboarders. Once at the road, a ride can be hitched into town or tacticians can call-in-route for a waiting taxi. Earlier in the day, the victim had already skied a nearby gully a couple of times.

Near the end of the day, the victim waited at the top of the ski area for his friend. Ironically, the night before, the two had talked about skiing this particular run, called D Chute, and decided against it. The power of powder overwhelmed their sense of self-preservation. Even though they both left their avalanche transceivers and shovels at home, the two decided to go for it. Both men were very experienced backcountry skiers and had skied the route many times over the years.

After the pair left the ski area boundary, the men encountered several collapses along with shooting cracks, up to 100+ feet in both directions from their ski tracks. They chose to keep going.

The small, soft-slab avalanche occurred in a small gully at about 9,000 feet on a generally easterly aspect high above Castle Creek. Though the slope faces toward the east, shadows cast by trees along its south edge keep part of the slope in shade. The snow on this shaded portion is similar to the weak sugar snow found on north-facing slopes. Preliminary estimates by the ski patrollers who performed the recovery put the dimensions of the slide at 75 feet across and about 100 feet long. The victim's friend used his ski poles to probe. It took about an hour to find and uncover his buried friend. His efforts at resuscitation were unsuccessful.

The man skied down to the Castle Creek road and flagged down a ride into town, where he reported the accident. The following morning, the Aspen Highlands Ski Patrol retrieved the body.

An Avalanche Warning was in effect at the time of the accident, and the backcountry danger was HIGH. Both natural and human-triggered avalanches were likely, and backcountry travel was discouraged.

SUMMARY
On Sunday afternoon at about 1300 hours, two snowshoers were caught in a shallow avalanche on the east-southeast face of Russell Peak, aka Russell Face. The couple had hiked westward from the Berthoud Pass Ski Area to the top of the chairlift and then continued westward toward the Continental Divide. At the top of the "Face," the couple stopped for a break, and he removed his snowshoes and stood them up vertically in the snow. A strong gust of wind knocked his snowshoes over the edge, and he went to retrieve them. A short distance below the edge, the 28-year-old Missouri triggered a small slab avalanche and was swept over a short cliff. He suffered a broken clavicle or collarbone. The 30-year-old Denver woman walked to the edge to check on her friend. The couple yelled back and worth a few times; he alerted her that his snowshoes were lost and warned her not to come down. She likely crept just over the edge to better hear her friend when the entire face released. The slab fractured behind the woman in a relatively flat area and swept her over rocks and cliffs. She suffered serious head, neck, and pelvic injuries. She died in a Denver hospital 3 days later.

RESCUE
Rescuers from Alpine Rescue Team, Berthoud Pass Ski Patrol, and Loveland Ski Patrol participated in the rescue. Flight for Life flew the victim to St. Anthony's hospital where she died from her injuries 3 days later.

location_name: St. Mary's Glacier, northwest of Idaho Springs
description:
At about 1130 hours on Wednesday, a 38-year-old Littleton woman was buried and killed in an avalanche on St. Mary's Glacier. She and a friend were hiking along the steep left side of the glacier slipped and slid down the steep snow-covered slope. At the bottom of the slope, she stood up and started to climb back to her friend. She triggered the avalanche as she started up the slope. Her friend was some distance above and to the side was also caught. The slab avalanche swept both of them down. He was able to free himself quickly and started looking for his friend.

The survivor searched for about 30 minutes before other hikers joined the search. After about 40 plus minutes, word reached the Clear Creek County Sheriff's Office and a rescue effort started. Rescuers found the victim about two hours after the avalanche. An arm and a leg were protruding from the snow.

Searching avalanche debris is a very difficult proposition. Without avalanche rescue beacons and shovels, the search for a buried person is literally the same as the search for a needle in a haystack.

A 43-year-old out-of-bounds skier from Aspen was killed in a sizable slab avalanche beyond the boundary of the Aspen Mountain Ski Area. The man was skiing alone when he likely triggered the avalanche on Sunday (March 8) on a treed area called Ophir Gulch. It is believed that he entered the slope from the side and undercut a steeper slope above, and triggered the avalanche. The avalanche started midway down the slope and left a lot of slab hanging above the fracture line.

No one reported the man overdue. Paragliders first noticed the avalanche on Tuesday, but it was not until Wednesday that paragliders saw the body. The avalanche occurred below the Ruthie's launch area near the top of the mountain. Members of the Aspen Mountain Ski Patrol were able to reach the body, but because of unstable snow conditions could not evacuate the body until Thursday morning. It appears the victim died of injuries sustained during the avalanche.

A "euphoric" day turned to tragedy when a 20-year-old backcountry snowboarder was buried and killed in a sizable slab avalanche on the south and west side of Berthoud Pass in Colorado. The victim and a skier friend triggered the avalanche as they skied down a steep backcountry area above treeline known as the Russell Face.
The two men used snowshoes to hike westward from the summit of Berthoud Pass toward the Continental Divide. The pair was 3 to 4 turns down the slope when it fractured. The avalanche swept the victim down and buried him under about two feet of snow. His partner had his skis knocked off his feet, which likely allowed him to stay on the surface. When the avalanche stopped, he briefly searched for his buried friend, but since they carried no avalanche rescue gear, he started hiking out to the highway, where he flagged down a motorist.

The Berthoud Pass Ski Patrol responded with support from the Alpine Rescue Team and the Loveland Ski Area Ski Patrol. They found the victim quickly and started CPR, but the almost 2-hour burial was too long.

location_name: San Bernardo Mountain, southwest of Ophir
description:
SUMMARY
A 25-year-old backcountry snowboarder was buried and killed in a very small slab avalanche on the east side of San Bernardo Mountain in southwestern Colorado. The victim and another man (a skier) borrowed beacons and snowshoes and hiked up San Bernardo Mountain southwest of Ophir (near Lizard Head Pass) to ski and ride the chutes on the east face of the mountain. They were accompanied by a dog. Wearing snowshoes for the ascent, it took the men about 3 hours to climb up the south side of the mountain.

The men had already descended about 1,000 vertical feet in suspect snow conditions. The skier was having a difficult time. He kept breaking through the upper layers of the snowpack into the sugar snow, causing falls or causing him to get stuck. The two men separated, and the victim continued his descent while the skier untangled himself. The skier continued down and saw a small avalanche with tracks into and out of the debris. He thought the tracks belonged to his friend, so he followed the tracks. A ways down slope, he found the dog and quickly realized the tracks out of the avalanche did not belong to his friend but rather to the dog. At that point, he put his snowshoes back on and climbed upslope to find the avalanche debris had piled into an old prospect hole.

The skier used his beacon to locate his friend. He was buried in a standing position with his head about 3 feet deep. Rescue came too late. After a burial of 30 to 40 minutes, the victim had likely died from suffocation. The skier and dog left to report the accident. The next morning, rescuers recovered the body.

COMMENTS
This accident is a classic example of how even a very small avalanche can turn deadly when the debris piles into a terrain trap. The pair were thinking avalanche before they left, and had beacons (borrowed) and shovels. They apparently stopped thinking avalanche when they started up the trail. Perhaps they were too focused on their goal to ski/ride the east side of San Bernardo Mountain. That we don't know, but we do know that this accident also shows how a couple of small and seemingly innocent mistakes can lead to tragedy.

The men's first mistake unknowingly started with their ascent of the mountain. They followed the locals' standard approach to the summit that took them up a drainage far away from their descent route. The climb took them up a south-facing slope with very different snow...more stable...conditions than their east-facing descent route. Once onto the east-facing terrain, the snow conditions likely changed very quickly, especially as they descended and encountered less deep snow.

A more serious mistake occurred when the pair separated. They had already descended at least a thousand vertical feet in less-than-good skiing conditions when the victim kept going...for some reason. Once out of sight of each other, the skier did not know what had happened to his friend until later, when he found the dog. By the time he reacted, it was too late.

A more serious clue indicating they stopped thinking avalanche was the snow conditions. The skier kept breaking through into sugar snow and getting stuck in the loose snow. Sugar snow, topped with firmer snow, are two key ingredients for slab avalanches. Had they been thinking avalanche, they likely would have recognized the snow conditions meant avalanches, stuck together, and always traveled in sight of each other. Had the skier witnessed the avalanche, he likely would have dug his friend out in minutes. The outcome could have been different.

Travel in avalanche terrain means never letting your guard down. Little mistakes like different ascent and descent routes, or temporarily separating from your partners, may not seem serious; however, in terms of avalanches, the consequences of these minor actions can be deadly.

SUMMARY
Two men were snowshoeing behind a cabin near Duck Lake, just over a mile south of Guanella Pass, when they triggered a slab avalanche. The weather was pleasant: blue skies, gusty winds, and mild temperatures. At about 1300 hours, the men were crossing beneath a short but steep slope through a small area of willows when they heard "a thud". The snow under their feet collapsed, and like pulling out a log from the bottom of a wood pile, released the slab avalanche from above. The men were about 15 feet apart, and the avalanche caught one but missed the other. He quickly looked for his friend, without success, so he dashed back to the cabin where they and their families were staying. The cabin was about 200 feet away.

From the cabin, the Clear Creek County Sheriff's Office was notified, and rescue teams were notified. The victim's friend and their wives quickly returned to the avalanche to look for the buried man. They knew basically where to look and started digging; unfortunately, they were off by a few feet. After about 45 minutes, the CCC Sheriff and another officer arrived. The sheriff took a ski pole and cut off the basket to fashion a probe pole. He started to show the others how to use the pole when he immediately probed the buried man. The 39-year-old California man was buried under 2 to 3 feet of snow near the toe (bottom) of the debris for nearly an hour.

He was quickly dug out, and resuscitation efforts started. A Flight for Life helicopter from Denver soon arrived, and advanced life support efforts were tried without luck.

COMMENTS
This accident occurred in the early season when the general snow cover was still very shallow and, to the untrained eye, no source of danger. Recent strong winds had stripped much snow off the surrounding mountains. However, the four fundamental requirements for a slab avalanche were present. First was the steep slope, though it was a very short slope; slope angle is more important than size. Second, there was the weak layer of sugar snow that provided a poor base for the firmer snow above. Third was the slab, a thick and cohesive layer of wind-deposited snow. At this point, the slope only needed a trigger, and tragically, that final requirement was provided when the two men snowshoed across the bottom of the slope.

This accident illustrates three important lessons for backcountry travelers. First, shallow snow can harbor avalanche danger, especially where winds have drifted snow onto steeper slopes. Second, short and small slopes are just as deadly as long, big slopes. Third, avalanches can be triggered from below, especially when weak faceted (sugar) is supporting a slab layer. It is important to know that most avalanches release from slopes of 30 to 45 degrees in steepness, and equally, it is just as important to learn that avalanches can occur when the snow fails on less-steep terrain. If the snow cover is consistent, not broken up by rocky areas, thick vegetation, or timber, the fractures can propagate along the weak layer to steeper slopes above and release the slab.

SUMMARY
Gladstone Peak (13,913 feet) is a spectacular-looking peak located between two more famous 14er neighbors, Mt. Wilson and Wilson Peak. At about 1400 hours on Saturday afternoon, two Colorado climbers were caught by a natural wet-slab avalanche high on Gladstone Peak. The pair was traversing a snowfield about 100 feet below the summit when they triggered the avalanche. Details are still sketchy; however, it appears the pair were on a small rock ledge that crumbled beneath them, triggering a small wet-slab avalanche. One man was carried a very short distance and suffered only cuts and bruises. The other victim, a 23-year-old Castle Rock man, was carried about 150 to 200 vertical feet and partly buried. He apparently died from serious head injuries suffered during his short ride. He was not wearing a helmet.

Two other friends were on the ridge above the pair but did not see the avalanche. They only learned of the tragedy when the one slightly injured climber was able to scramble back to the ridge. Not equipped for steep snow travel, the three were unable to descend to their friend, so they left to get help. At a campground lower on the mountain, they borrowed a cellular telephone to alert the San Miguel Sheriff's Department.

A rapid response got rescuers to the victim by about 1700 hours. They then evacuated the body.

COMMENTS
Falling rock and avalanches are certainly among the dangers climbers face when tackling the rugged and rotten summits of the San Miguel Mountains. Though this group suffered bad luck, their accident was typical of many that occur in the mountains. Warm temperatures, late afternoons, rotten rock, shallow wet snow, and steep slopes are key ingredients to rockfall and avalanches. Add to this list the group's inexperience, lack of proper equipment, and poor decision-making, and you have the recipe for disaster. Sadly, these ingredients came together on Gladstone Peak. This accident is a grim reminder that even in summer, avalanches can still threaten the visitors to steep, high-elevation slopes.
This was the first [and only] Colorado avalanche fatality of the 1996-97 avalanche season (Sept. 1 to Aug. 31). It was the 20th avalanche fatality in the US this season.

SAFETY TIP
Summertime climbers and skiers should avoid shallow, wet snow even at the high elevations. Even on big snowfields, extra care is needed along the snowfield's margins where the snow is shallow. (My working definition of shallow is a snow cover less than a meter deep.) Shallow snow tends to be unstable snow both in winter (for different reasons) and summer. Shallow snow tends to be less dense or compacted, so it is also weaker. During the summer, melting further weakens the snow. In a shallow summer snow cover, the meltwater quickly saturates the snow and also quickly lubricates potential sliding layers such as rock, dirt, or grass. Often, all that is needed for the avalanche is a trigger: a climber, skier, snowboarder, cornice, or rock fall.

Fresh snow on old snow should also not be trusted for the same reasons as mentioned above. Melting will quickly weaken the new snow and the water will quickly lubricate the hard, icy, old snow below.

HISTORICAL JULY AVALANCHE ACCIDENTS
July 23, 1994, Mt. Hood, Oregon, two climbers caught buried and killed.
The last Colorado avalanche victim killed during July occurred on July 4, 1976, on Mt. Ypsilon. Though that accident was unwitnessed, the avalanche is suspected to have been caused when a portion of the cornice collapsed onto the steep snow slope the victim was climbing. The following year, on July 3, 1977, two climbers were caught and injured, also on Mt. Ypsilon, when a huge portion of cornice collapsed above them.

The worst July avalanche accident in the US occurred on July 22, 1939, on Mt. Baker (Washington) when a group of 25 college students was caught by a shallow soft-slab avalanche. Six were buried and killed.

SUMMARY
At about 1400 hours on Tuesday, two local Aspen snowboarders left the Aspen Highlands Ski Area below the Steeplechase runs to ride to the valley floor. At about 9,000 feet, a 30-year-old rider triggered and was caught in a small WL [wet loose] slide that was only as wide as his snowboard. At first, the slide did not seem like much, but as the wet snow continued to ooze down the hill, it grew in size to about 40 feet across. The victim's partner watched his friend "riding the white tiger" head into relatively thick aspens.
Once the snow started to slide, the victim described the wet snow as "quick sand" from which he could not escape. His ride in the slide was "like being in a cement mixer," especially when he was slammed through the aspens. Not only did the avalanche break trees, but it also ripped his binding from his board. With his feet free he was able to "swim with the avalanche," and after a ride of about 500 feet, he was able to grab a tree with his legs as the avalanche slowed to a stop.
After the avalanche stopped, the second rider hurried down to help his injured friend. The victim was "pretty beat-up," and by his own admission, he looked like "he had been in a bar fight with a couple of cats." The pair used their avalanche shovels as small crutches to assist the injured man's walk (about 100 feet) to the road and their car. After a painful hobble to the car, they headed to the emergency department at Aspen Valley Hospital, where the victim was admitted with multiple contusions and abrasions, a fractured rib, and a fractured lumbar vertebra (#4).

The man admits he was very lucky. When his snowboard was ripped from his boots, he gained some mobility that helped him swim with the slide, but it was his helmet and his backpack that likely saved his life. During the avalanche, he struck trees with his back and head, yet he was able to walk away from "the white tiger." He is expected to make a complete recovery.

COMMENTS
The pair were well-equipped and carried avalanche rescue gear, but were not expecting trouble. The victim had ridden the same line 12 to 15 times this season, and on the day before (Monday), he rode a different line, but it was similar in terms of aspect, elevation, and steepness. The victim stated they did not dig a hasty pit, but if they had, he was not sure it would have changed their decision. He added that if they had dug a pit, it would have been at the top of their route, where they encountered stable snow. The avalanche released was much lower down.

As a "Monday morning quarterback," it is easy to say the two started late in the day for a relatively low elevation excursion during the first significant thaw of the season, but who of us hasn't done the same thing! Nonetheless, there were several mistakes made that he hopes others will not make. First, as any investor knows, past performance does not indicate future returns. The same must be said when dealing with avalanches. It does not matter how many times you might have skied/ridden a steep slope in the past. Past actions give no indication of today's stability; this is especially true during spring-like conditions when snow stability can change greatly over short periods. Their second error was their failure to recognize changing snow conditions. For most of us, this skill comes with time spent in the mountains, and these two riders learned plenty on Tuesday afternoon. Some days, the changing snow conditions are obvious, while on other days the changes are more subtle, but it is on these days that one must take the time and look for the changes. When obvious clues to avalanche danger are not apparent, it takes time (a long time) to experience, learn, and understand how differences in temperatures can combine with snowpack depths, vegetation ground cover, elevations, and aspects to affect the snow stability. If you are uncertain of avalanche conditions, increase your margin of safety. But even when you are certain, as this injured rider said, "expect the unexpected." On a bright note, this incident demonstrated the importance of keeping your backpack securely on your back, where it will give some protection. Another important piece of safety equipment worn by the victim was a helmet. A piece of safety equipment we normally tend not to think about when skiing and snowboarding, especially in avalanche terrain...but on that Tuesday afternoon, it made a difference.

location_name: Rocky Mountain National Park, Twin Owls Crag
description: A climber fell 12 meters while rappelling after a single hexcentric anchor failed, resulting in head lacerations, back and abdomen tenderness, and abrasions.

A climber fell approximately 20 meters while rappelling after failing to properly clip both rope loops through the locking carabiner on their figure-eight device; the climber sustained serious injuries despite wearing a helmet.
F.E. fell into a crevasse on Crowfoot Mountain while hiking alone without crampons or an ice ax, but was uninjured and rescued after 55 hours.
A climber fell ten meters into a crevasse on the Crescent Glacier after climbing Bugaboo Spire, but was rescued by his partner.
A ski tourer fell into a crevasse, followed by another who fell while attempting rescue. One person died after being rescued from the crevasse.
J.N. fell through a snow bridge into a hole with a hidden creek while descending unroped from Mount Nublock, resulting in a fatality.
A climber fell 30 meters on the Elevator Shaft route on Mount Johnson after a snow and ice formation collapsed, resulting in a fractured hip and subsequent avalanches impacting the climbers.
A climber fell 25 meters while ice climbing in Rob’s Ravine on Carson Peak, sustaining leg injuries.

location_name: Ruth Gorge, Mount Johnson, East Buttress
description: A climber fell three meters after a rock flake broke while leading a new route on Mount Johnson, resulting in a right ankle and foot injury; the party self-rescued.
A climber leading a 5.10b route fell after wired chocks pulled out, resulting in a fractured sternum and strained back muscles.
A climber fell approximately 20 meters while descending Cathedral Peak without ropes or protection, sustaining a head injury and a serious leg injury.
A climber fell 300 meters to his death while solo climbing the East Face of Mount Wardle without protection due to inexperience; his brother injured his ankle and turned back.

location_name: Charlevoix Mountains, Mont du Gros Bras
description: A climber fell 100 meters while solo climbing Hallunbeinbrunch on Mont du Gros Bras, sustaining fatal injuries.
A climber fell while free-soloing "Hobbit Roof" after missing a hand jam, resulting in a shattered heel.

A climber leading the fifth pitch of Dropout on Mount Rundle pulled out a large block and fell 25 meters, sustaining serious injuries including a cracked pelvis and broken heel; the belayer held the fall and a rescue was required.
Larry Forsyth fell eight meters while leading Flying Kiwi after two pieces of protection pulled out, resulting in a fractured lower lumber vertebra.
A climber fell while leading a new route, hit his head, and was knocked unconscious; a helmet would have reduced the injury.
Manuel Afonso suffered multiple fractures after falling approximately 12 meters when his rope was cut while he was ascending a fixed line to take photographs.
A solo climber slipped on snow near Denali Pass, fell 200 meters over crevasses, and sustained a sprained ankle and contusions, self-evacuating to the airstrip.
A climber descending the Mountaineers Route on Mount Whitney without crampons or ice axes fell on snow and slid approximately 210 meters, striking rocks and sustaining fatal injuries.

Two climbers fell while ascending the West Shoulder Direct route on Mount Andromeda due to inadequate protection and a pulled belay. One climber died from a head injury, and the other sustained a concussion, hypothermia, and lacerations.

location_name: Rocky Mountains, Columbia Icefield, Snow Dome
description: William fell through a cornice while unroped and looking for a descent route after completing an ascent of Slipstream; he was never found.
A climber was ascending Green Butte Ridge on Mount Shasta when a large rock slab he stepped on slid down, trapping and breaking his leg. He self-rescued and was eventually assisted by skiers.

location_name: Rocky Mountains, Ice Caves near Bragg Creek
description: A climber scrambling at the entrance to ice caves was killed when a rock formation collapsed on top of him.
A climber was struck on the head by a falling rock while ascending a steep snow gully on Mount Waddington, resulting in fatal injuries.
A climber was struck by a rock dislodged by another team's rope while climbing the East Face route on Mount Whitney, resulting in minor injuries.

location_name: Rocky Mountain National Park, Lamb’s Slide
description: A climbing party traversing Lamb's Slide fell after the leader dislodged a rock and pulled out protection; the belayer was unanchored and also fell, resulting in injuries to both climbers.
Katie Kemble was belaying Ric Hatch on the Ophir Wall when she was struck by a rockfall, resulting in the amputation of her left lower leg.

location_name: Rocky Mountain National Park, Eagle Cliff Mountain
description: Tricia Timms was struck in the hip by a 14 kg rock dislodged by a rappeller in her party while sitting at the base of a cliff band.
A climber was struck by falling rock in a gully on Mount Buller, leading to a fatal fall.
